Headline: WSJ(4/7) Starwood CEO's Ouster Followed Battle With Board
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Peter Sanders and Joann S. Lublin   The abrupt departure of Steven J. Heyer from Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc. followed a confrontation with the company's board ignited by an anonymous letter accusing him of personal misconduct, according to people familiar with the situation.   Mr. Heyer -- who denies engaging in any impropriety -- was unexpectedly ousted as chief executive officer this past week, and in the process opted to forfeit an estimated $35 million of severance compensation.   Mr. Heyer, who had been president and chief operating officer of Coca-Cola Co. before taking over at Starwood in 2004, has long been known for brusque, often difficult relations with employees. After investigating claims made in the anonymous letter, sent to directors about two months ago, board members pressed Mr. Heyer to explain the large number of emails and text messages between him and female employees on a variety of topics outside normal working hours. They also questioned him about his relationship with one particular female employee and about his hiring and promotion practices.   Starwood's chairman and interim CEO, Bruce Duncan, has declined to comment on the specific reasons behind Mr. Heyer's departure. On Friday, a spokeswoman for Starwood, which counts Westin, Sheraton, St. Regis and W hotels among its brands, reiterated the company's earlier statement that the board had lost confidence in Mr. Heyer's leadership, but added that "his style made some employees uncomfortable."   In an interview, the 54-year-old Mr. Heyer characterized the situation as the ugly fallout from extensive strategic and structural changes he made while "transforming [Starwood] from a real-estate hotel company to a branding company." He says he doesn't know who wrote or sent the letter, but believes it could have been someone passed over for a promotion.   "For an anonymous letter to basically destroy a reputation would be sinful," Mr. Heyer said. While acknowledging he can be a difficult boss, he said the chain of events set off by the letter represented the "straw that broke the camel's back" in his increasingly poor relationship with the company.   He left without his severance package because "life is too short" to mount a contested defense against the allegations. "I'm burned out," he added. "I wanted to walk away from this job with my head held high."   Starwood's board hired an outside law firm, Davis Polk & Wardwell, to investigate the letter's allegations, people familiar with the matter say. In the course of the probe, Mr. Heyer's emails and text messages were scrutinized and found to include an "overwhelming body of evidence" that would have given the board reason to fire him for cause, according to the person familiar with the situation. His employment contract lists five reasons directors could fire him for cause, one of them being "gross negligence or willful misconduct."   The investigation uncovered emails and text messages between Mr. Heyer, who is married, and a young, unmarried female employee that were sent at times outside normal business hours and were of a suggestive nature. "There were several provocative conversations, and there was no question that the conduct was inappropriate for a CEO," this person said.   Mr. Heyer said allegations of sexual advances made toward younger female employees "are absolutely not true, they never happened." In regard to inappropriate email and text messages, Mr. Heyer said, "To the best of my knowledge I didn't send any, and I don't remember receiving any." He said the board didn't specifically question him about the content of his messages, but rather about the volume of notes he sent and received.   Mr. Heyer's departure comes at a time of prosperity in the industry. When he arrived at the company, its shares were trading around $47 per share. On the Friday before he resigned, they sold for about $64 apiece. The company, like rivals Marriott International Inc. and Hilton Hotels Corp., has raised room rates as robust consumer and business travel have bolstered demand. Starwood's earnings rose during Mr. Heyer's tenure, owing in part to a large transaction of hotel real estate announced in November 2005. In 2006, Starwood reported net income of $1.04 billion on $5.97 billion of revenue. The prior year, Starwood reported net income of $422 million on similar sales.   The board's quick move to seek Mr. Heyer's ouster may be the culmination of simmering tensions over his leadership style, which have built up over time despite satisfaction with the company's performance and Mr. Heyer's strategy. But it also reflects the growing desire by corporate boards to act decisively when presented with evidence of possible executive misconduct. In 2005, for example, Boeing Co. acted swiftly to replace then-CEO Harry Stonecipher after emails revealed a relationship with a female Boeing executive; Boeing said Mr. Stonecipher, who was married at the time, was fired not for having an affair, but for violating Boeing's code of conduct. Mr. Stonecipher acknowledged his conduct.   The letter received by Starwood board members in mid-February contained about 10 specific instances that allegedly showed Mr. Heyer had created a hostile work environment since arriving at Starwood in October 2004, according to a person familiar the details of the situation. The letter alleged, for example, that on at least one occasion Mr. Heyer made inappropriate physical contact with a female employee outside a restaurant bathroom, this person said. Mr. Heyer denied to the board and in an interview Friday that such an incident ever occurred.   This same female employee last summer accompanied Mr. Heyer and five other Starwood employees on the corporate jet to a board meeting in Greece. Mr. Heyer said this employee was part of the "Generation Next" program he created to cultivate younger homegrown managers, in what he says is a "generation-skipping exercise" authorized by the company. This person was part of that project, and Mr. Heyer said he often took employees on trips aboard the jet to do work while flying. He cited a recent trip on which Starwood's general counsel accompanied him to Spain simply to do work on the flight there and back. "We got work done and we thought it would be fun."   People familiar with the situation say Mr. Heyer was also questioned by the board about his method of promoting employees and whether he fostered a culture of favoritism. He says he responded to this question by noting that all promotions were done through a process and he wasn't on the promotion committee.   Nonetheless, the board determined that the women who had exchanged email and text message with Mr. Heyer were essentially "unwilling victims" who felt pressured to curry favor with the CEO, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.   Mr. Heyer's departure capped a stormy two-and-a-half year run at the top of Starwood. After arriving from Coke -- where he had been passed over for the top job -- Mr. Heyer was hired by Starwood at a time when then-CEO Barry Sternlicht was looking for someone to replace him.   But Mr. Sternlicht and Starwood directors were aware of Mr. Heyer's reputation for a rough management style. Starwood directors received an extensive briefing about Mr. Heyer's difficult personality before they chose him as CEO.   "They went into this with eyes open," says one person familiar with his hiring process. They learned in "nauseous detail" about the former Coke president's frequent clashes with colleagues there, this person says. The hotel chain's due diligence included conversations with Coke board members who told Starwood recruiters that Mr. Heyer didn't get the corner office at the beverage giant in part because he was so difficult to work with.   But Mr. Heyer impressed the Starwood board with his marketing background and his plans for the company's hotel brands. Upon his arrival, he clashed with Mr. Sternlicht, who had moved to the executive chairman seat. In May 2005, Mr. Sternlicht abruptly left Starwood and his seat on the board. Over the next year and a half, Mr. Heyer announced two new hotel brands, acquired the Le Meridien brand, sold a large chunk of Starwood's real-estate portfolio and announced a variety of branding and marketing promotions with a variety of consumer-product and service firms.   In recent months, the Starwood board began to discuss its misgivings about Mr. Heyer. Among its biggest gripes: Mr. Heyer spent little time at headquarters in White Plains, instead commuting from his home in Atlanta. Under Mr. Heyer's contract, Starwood provided an Atlanta area office, but the CEO agreed to spend "at least a majority" of his workdays over a two-month period either at headquarters or on company business trips.   Since Mr. Heyer's departure, Starwood shares have hit new highs on speculation the company is now a prime buyout target. The stock hit an all-time high of $71.79 a share on Wednesday in intraday trading on the New York Stock Exchange, before closing at $70.08 on Thursday ahead of the long holiday weekend.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 04:00 ET (08:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Streetwise: Is The Selling Over?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   For decades, a myth has held that the New York Stock Exchange closes on Good Friday because, in the distant past, it opened on the day and a market crash resulted, imbuing the exchange's governors with justified fear of the supernatural.   Art Cashin, the longtime floor broker with UBS, debunked this chestnut last week in an edition of his pithy and perceptive daily market commentary. Yet even without a visit to the archives, Friday's action in the electronic index-futures arena would have disproved the notion that trading stocks on Good Friday invites bad luck.   In the 45 minutes that index futures were open for screen-based business following Friday's surprisingly sturdy employment report, the S&P 500 futures gained nearly a half-percent and the Nasdaq contract rose a bit more than that, even as Treasury yields spurted higher on reduced hopes for a Federal Reserve rate cut soon.   This reflex move will, be assured, bring countless assertions on Wall Street's Monday morning strategy calls that the subprime-mortgage, Chinese-selloff, economic-growth scare of 2007 has passed. The fact that the indexes have recouped all but about 1% of the losses that began with the late-February tumble will only stiffen the bulls' resolve that it was all just a chilling, but fleeting, late-winter nightmare.   Could that be all there is to the selling? It's possible, at least for the immediate term. But it's hard to get too excited about how enticing the upside is from here, given the investor-sentiment picture and the fundamental unkowns.   The charts to the right show the market's pullbacks and recoveries, one each year, since 2004. Each retreat has (so far) been shallower than the preceding one. Buying the breaks has been rewarded, and to date the buying has come earlier with each decline, as bidders try to beat the crowd. It will work until it doesn't.   The sentiment setup before the selloff wasn't as giddy as at past market highs, as noted here, which implied that the damage wouldn't "be real nasty." Yet if the early March lows prove out as the lows for the year, it would have been an extremely brief convalescence, and also the earliest date that the market hit its calendar-year low since 2003 (and before that, 1996).   These lows will have happened without the kind of investor despondency that has led to the ripest buying chances in recent years, too. Consider a rough sentiment gauge, the weekly Investors Intelligence newsletter writers' bulls versus bears. The most negative reading of March was 45% bulls and 29% bears. That's similar to what we saw at the 2005 market low, but a far cry from the 36% bulls/36% bears of last summer, which preceded a 20% surge in the indexes.   A cursory scan at the past six weeks' market action makes it resemble a textbook selloff, leading to a short-term low, with a downward rush quickly reversed, then a near-retest of that low and further recovery. Now the buyers will face a serious test as the former highs are approached.   Anyone looking for the "all clear" should carry a checklist of things needed to help the cause. Trading volume ought to increase on rallies, especially among real-money buyers. Financial stocks, still more than 3% below their highs, better strengthen before long. The 10-year Treasury yield, which rose to 4.75% Friday, had better not cross the 4.9% level that's spelled difficulty for stocks in the past. And the downward revisions of first-quarter earnings forecasts to a 3.4% annual growth level need to have dropped expectations low enough for relief buying to take hold as the results come in. Too much to ask? We'll see.   The announced leveraged buyout of First Data (ticker: FDC) last week offered temporary vindication to those following the ubiquitous screens of LBO candidates. First Data -- an under-leveraged company with steady cash flow -- was a staple of such lists.   Yet there are signs that too many pockets of the market already price in some LBO premium, leaving the risk of downside if no deal occurs or debt markets get woozy.   Vadim Zlotnikov, strategist at Sanford C. Bernstein, calls the LBO bets part of a "bubble of stability" -- widespread trades, principally by hedge funds, based on assumptions that markets will remain calm and generous. He's scanned the smaller-cap universe for stocks with concentrated hedge-fund ownership, low trading liquidity and a premium valuation, which could mean outsized risk should the "stability trade" expire. Some names to be wary of: Corrections Corp. of America (CXW), Bisys (BSG), EFunds (EFD), Catalina Marketing (POS), Granite Construction (GVA), Gemstar TV Guide (GMST), Gartner (IT) and Del Monte Foods (DLM).   These stocks remain hazardous to short. But those hoping to hit the private-equity lottery with any of them should recognize that faster money has gotten there first.   ---   E-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Speaking Of Dividends: Upward Bias: Dividend Activity Remains Strong; Extras Climb 7.8%
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Corporate caution about boosting dividends continued into 2007's first quarter. For the third consecutive three-month stretch, fewer companies enhanced their payouts than in the corresponding year-earlier period. Yet overall dividend activity remains strong.   Standard & Poor's totted up 621 payout hikes among the approximately 7,000 publicly owned companies that report to its Dividend Record service. That's 0.8% below the 626 in 2006's first quarter.   The numberofextra disbursements, however, rose 7.8%, to 111 from 103. These are issued by companies that might have sweetened their regular payouts, but decided to pay a bonus, too. Also included are payouts from corporations that want to play it safe by not committing to a higher regular dividend that might be unsustainable if the going gets too tough.   In addition, eight companies resumed paying dividends, one more than did so a year earlier.   Overall, notes S&P, the number of dividend payments keeps rising; year to date, it's up 5.6%. And aggregate cash payments have increased 16% for listed shares.   "The improvement in dividends has slowed down its pace since the 2003 start, with companies remaining cautious about committing future funding and preferring to increase their stock-buyback programs instead," said Howard Silverblatt, S&P's senior index analyst. However, "dividend reductions continue to be low, reflecting the more assured approach to payments once the commitment is made."   On that score, there were 13 payout cuts in the January-March period, versus 11 over the same period last year. Omissions totaled six both this year and last.   The ratio of dividend boosts to negative actions in the first quarter was 32.7-to-1.   Financial-adviser Bryan Perry is high on a pair of covered-call income closed-end funds that he's betting can stand up to the stock market's volatility. (Perry and his newsletter, the 25% Cash Machine, were briefly discussed in this space Feb. 12.) Both funds are priced around 20 and yield more than 10%.   The first is BlackRock Enhanced Equity Yield & Premium (ticker: ECV). Perry is attracted to it because it's "megacap and blue-chip in its portfolio composition" and concentrated in the stocks he believes have strong upside potential into 2008. "I want us to get in on the broad rally, but we need to be paid well along the way."   The other is Small Cap Premium & Dividend Income (RCC). Perry finds this fund notable because "the level of volatility in the market is actually good news for option income funds, [since] they are structured to derive the majority of their income from writing or selling covered calls on the underlying portfolio of stocks."   He adds that what's really cool about the RCC fund is that its managers "are only writing covered calls on half the portfolio, leaving 50% of what they own open to the pure upside."   One of the nation's largest diversified financial-services providers, super-regional PNC Financial Services Group (PNC), voted on Thursday to boost its dividend by 15%. The new payout will be 63 cents a share, versus 55 cents. Disbursement is set for April 24 to investors on the books April 13. The stock goes ex-dividend April 11. Yield: 3.46%.   Including predecessor companies, Pittsburgh-based PNC has paid dividends without interruption since 1865.   Traded on the New York Stock Exchange, PNC set a 52-week high of 76.41 Feb. 20. It's now a bit below that level.   PNC has a 34% stake in fund manager BlackRock (BLK), having merged the rest of it with Merrill Lynch's asset-management unit in 2006. BlackRock oversees more than $1.1 trillion of assets.   Last month, PNC completed its $6 billion acquisition of Baltimore-based Mercantile Bankshares. The combo, with some $119 billion in assets, makes PNC the 11th-largest U.S. banking organization.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) The Electronic Investor: Planning For April 15, 2008
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kathy Yakal   Why not put the misery of this tax season to work for you? Before the pain subsides too much, use it as motivation to tap into some Websites and programs that offer year-round tax help and can protect you from last-minute surprises. They might even save you some money.   For active traders, GainsKeeper (www.gainskeeper.com) has always been a favorite of ours. It's actually a suite of products -- with portfolio-tracking tools that can adjust the cost basis for wash sales and corporate actions, or  calculate capital-gains-related transactions. Another site feature offers portfolio strategies to minimize taxes and maximize after-tax returns while counseling you on how to diversify wisely. And Gains-Keeper will generate a Schedule D (or export to popular tax-preparation packages) and build gain/loss reports.   Just in time for the most recent tax season, the company, a part of Wolters Kluwer Financial Services, upgraded client services, including real-time support chat.   Taxpayers still smarting from having to write an unexpected check might want to keep an eye out for GainsKeeper enhancements coming later this year. Among them is an automated import tool that will grab data from financial institutions nightly. Functionality from a Wolters Kluwer product known as Basis Pro also will be integrated with GainsKeeper to calculate cost basis for investors who, say, change brokerages or inherit stock. A year-round trading and analysis tool will ensure that sells are most tax-efficient.   GainsKeeper has created several price levels, ranging from Investor150 (150 transactions per year for $59, reduced from  $69) to TraderElite (up to 100,000 transactions a year for $659). A free 30-day trial account includes everything but Schedule D, and lets you complete up to 25 trades.   It's hard to imagine at this time of year, but the U.S. government gives as well as takes. The Health Opportunity Patient Empowerment Act of 2006, designed to make health care more affordable for U.S. consumers, includes several changes to health-savings accounts. HSAs, in tandem with a high-deductible health-insurance plan, allow for tax-free savings that can be used for medical purposes. Among the changes incorporated in the Act is an increase in the annual HSA contribution, to $2,850 for an individual from $2,700, and $5,650 for families from $5,450. Among the other modifications are one-time transfers from IRAs to HSAs and greater employer contributions for lower-paid employees.   To learn more about these tax-saving vehicles, check out the companies that provide them, like Golden Rule Insurance Company (www.goldenrule.com), HSA Bank (www.hsabank.com), and Sterling HSA (www.sterlinghsa.com).   Kiplinger.com (www.kiplinger.com) has some of the best editorial content on taxes we've seen, and the site now plans to make this material available year-round, including a big new splash on 2007 taxes slated for January. Current offerings include "The 13 Most Overlooked Tax Deductions" (some of which I'd never heard of), and "Do It Yourself Tax Savings for 2007" (advice on making the right tax-related moves through 2007). I also liked a piece on 10 oddball deductions, including the one about a gas-station owner who was allowed to write off the cost of the beer he gave customers in lieu of trading stamps.   Year-round help is also available from the sources that provide tax-preparation tools; you can browse these any time during the year to remind yourself about things you should be considering and doing before December 31. There's Intuit's TurboTax site (www.turbotax.com) and H&R Block (www.hrblock.com), makers of TaxCut software.   Personal-finance portals MSN Money (moneycentral.msn.com), Yahoo! Finance (finance.yahoo.com) and AOL (www. aol.com) also provide advice and tools year-round (but not in as much volume after tax day). And don't forget the official IRS site, www.irs.gov, for year-round updates and forms.   We can recommend several blogs, including ataxingmatter (ataxingmatter.blogs.com/tax), penned by Wayne State University law school professor Linda Beale; TaxProf Blog (taxprof.typepad.com) from blogmaster Paul L. Caron, a law professor at the University of Cincinnati College of Law, and the Tax Foundation Tax Policy Blog (www.taxfoundation.org).   Meanwhile, if you're one of the many Americans interested in critical analysis of the tax system itself,  you can look for policy facts and figures as well as publications and papers on topics like options to fix the AMT at the Tax Policy Center (www.taxpolicycenter.org), a joint venture of the Urban Institute and Brookings Institution. You can even write your Congressperson if you're truly motivated.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Asian Trader: Hitachi s Power Play
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jamie Miyazaki   Hitachi has long been condemned by investors as the archetypal value-destroying conglomerate. Goldman Sachs estimates that the firm's return on invested capital hasn't beaten its weighted-average cost of capital for 12 years. Still, the oft-maligned outfit's shares have shown stellar returns since September, after hitting a 12-month low of 644 yen and trading well below book value.   Despite no Buy ratings among the 11 analysts who cover the company, Hitachi (ticker: 6501.TO) is up 16% this year alone, from its closing price at year-end 2006 of 810 yen. By comparison, the Nikkei 225 Stock Average has been essentially flat (closing price at year end was 17383.42). Hitachi is now selling at 936 yen, and traders say some investors are speculating the share price could top 1,000 yen -- a level Hitachi hasn't sustained since 2001, and which may be wishful thinking, given the still-paltry state of earnings.   What is undeniable is that Hitachi has been well positioned to ride two themes sweeping Tokyo's stock market: restructuring at tech companies and interest in nuclear-power stocks.   Expectations for earnings growth from Hitachi's power-system business have been piqued ever since November's tie-up with General Electric (GE) in the nuclear-power field. Throw in last year's Toshiba-Westinghouse deal and TXU's recent order for two reactors from Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (7011.TO), and that makes "nuclear power very topical; Hitachi has benefited a lot from that," says Toshihiro Atae, sales manager at brokerage Fimat in Tokyo.   It is also a prime candidate for a restructuring and cost-savings. Hitachi generated anemic operating margins of just 2.7% in its latest fiscal year, from a convoluted empire including 932 group companies. Matsushita Electric Industrial, in contrast, had  operating-profit margins of 4.7%.   Yet there are signs of improvement. Hitachi's new strategy to enhance profitability has  included: selling off its holding in its motor-production subsidiary Japan Servo (6585.TO) to Nidec (6594.OK); increasing its stake in audio-equipment maker Clarion; and merging subsidiary Hitachi Metals (5486.TO) with electromagnet maker Neomax. But given the dearth of earnings, how much further the stock can rise is debatable. Evidence of the hardships Hitachi is facing were  underlined last month, when it forecast a 200 billion yen parent loss for the 12 months ended March 2007, due to a massive writedown at its hard-disk-drive unit, repair costs to nuclear-reactor turbines, and poor sales of home appliances.   Nikko Citigroup analyst Yohei Kanazawa notes Hitachi has traded at an average price-to-book ratio of around 1.14 over the past decade; a 1,000 yen share price would equate to a PBR around 1.4, yet the synergies and savings may not boost the bottom line for years. For instance, even if Hitachi bags new contracts for nuclear plants, these wouldn't contribute to earnings until 2015, says Goldman.   Japanese filings show no significant new positions  accumulated year-to-date by  the company's two biggest shareholders, value managers Brandes Investment and Dodge & Cox; both have developed reputations for being savvy bargain hunters, and were  big buyers of Hitachi in the final  quarter of 2006. That suggests the margin of safety that most value investors look for when scouring for bargains no longer exists.   Hitachi seems to be moving in the right direction, but investors may have gotten ahead of themselves in thinking the stock will head much higher on fundamentals.   ---   Jamie Miyazaki is a reporter for Dow Jones Newswires in Tokyo.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Barron's Online: Amvescap Shakeup Brings Price Shakedown
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Demitra DeFotis   After key Amvescap portfolio managers and other employees defected to Deutsche Bank late last month, Amvescap's already-sagging stock looks especially cheap.   Shares in the London-based asset-management company, the product of the 1997 merger of AIM Investments and Invesco, have stumbled since the departures -- the subject of a court battle -- became known. The situation has been aggravated by the disclosure that Robert H. Graham, 60, Amvescap's vice chairman and AIM's co-founder, will retire.   At their recent price of 22.77, the company's American depositary receipts were 12.6% below their 52-week high of 26.05. The ADRs (ticker: AVZ) were trading at roughly 15 times estimated earnings for 2007, and about 13 times 2008 estimates  -- multiples that are well below the average for other asset managers, according to Thomson Financial/Baseline.   "It is a buying opportunity," says Niamh Alexander, an analyst at CIBC World Markets. "I do believe they have the right asset mix for sustainable growth."   Of Amvescap's roughly $460 billion in assets at the end of 2006, about a third was in fixed-income, money-market or alternative investments. More than half of Amvescap's assets are in the U.S.   Last September, Amvescap bought into one of the hottest trends in the investment world by acquiring PowerShares Capital Management, which constructs exchange-traded funds, or ETFs, based on indexes.   Currently, PowerShares has more than $9 billion in assets, almost $3 billion more than it held when the deal was closed six months ago. That growth is helping turn Amvescap's U.S. cash flows back to positive territory, CIBC's Alexander says.   He likes the track record of Amvescap CEO Martin Flanagan, who improved operating margins while at Franklin Resources, an investment-advisory firm. And he argues that Amvescap isn't getting credit for PowerShares' growth.   The ongoing restructuring began after the mutual-fund industry scandal in 2003 and 2004, which tarnished a host of companies.   Investigations focused on rapid trading that skimmed long-term shareholders' profits in mutual funds. AIM and Invesco agreed to pay millions in fines and to reduce fees. Then the asset bloodletting began.   That gave the stock a discount well before Deutsche Bank lured 16 people from Amvescap's fixed-income business two weeks ago. But importantly, the asset drain waned in 2006, with gross redemptions of $1.4 billion. Redemptions crested in 2004 at $19.5 billion; they amounted to $16.2 billion in 2005, according to Amvescap data.   More exposure to out-of-favor growth funds hurt, but investment returns are strengthening and should shore up the stock, Alexander says.   Indeed, Amvescap's returns on retail managed assets improved in 2006. In the United Kingdom, 89% of its assets under management ranked among the top half of peers based on performance, compared with 72% in 2005. In the United States, 60% of the company's funds ranked in the top half of their peer groups, versus 45% at the end of 2005, Amvescap reports.   Wall Street expects Amvescap to produce long-term earnings growth of 12%, just above the industry average of 11%, according to Baseline.   Few large-cap competitors trade at a discount as large as Amvescap's, based on the  ratio of its price-earnings multiple to expected long-term-growth.   "A bit of a discount to U.S. peers is warranted over the next few years as they [Amvescap] prove their ability to improve margins and turn flows positive -- but hopefully you narrow the gap," says analyst Douglas Rogers at Eaton Vance.   Of course, all asset managers will take a hit if the market goes south. But investors can take some  in Amvescap's asset diversification and minimal exposure to sub-prime-lending risks, which limited its recent market hit, writes William R. Katz, an analyst at Buckingham Research Group.   And with Amvescap fighting any further exodus of personnel, investors may want to be the next ones to swoop in -- into Amvescap stock.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Commodities Corner: The Unemployment Rate's Next Move: Up?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lisa Kallal   Barley is to beer what grapes are to wine. so with world barley supplies forecast to fall to an 11-year-low by July, beer enthusiasts might want to savor their favorite brew.   "The market is totally dry of barley," Heineken's (ticker: 00916.Netherlands) CEO Jean-Francois van Boxmeer said in late February, when the company released its yearly results. The shortage has pushed European Union malting-barley cash-market prices up 80% in the past 12 months. Prices also jumped in other major producing nations, including the U.S., Canada and Australia.   With global weather patterns becoming more volatile, droughts may increase, industry experts say. Additionally, the greater focus on biofuels to curb auto emissions is leading to a competition for cultivable land, including area seeded for malting barley. A severe drought slashed Australia's 2006 harvest by 60%, and amid President Bush's biofuel push, U.S. barley acreage harvested last year sank to its lowest level since 1885.   Steve Edwardson, executive director of the North Dakota Barley Council, says that corn and soybeans are pushing into traditional barley-growing areas due to attractive prices and improved, northern growing-zone versions of the crops. North Dakota is the largest barley-producing state, with up to 90% of its crop targeted for malt. Rising demand for biofuels crops gives E.U. farmers more planting choices, says Marieke de Rijke, barley analyst with Netherlands-based Rabobank. "It's a structural shift," de Rijke adds.   Price pressures have "added to our overall cost of goods in the U.S.," says Kabira Hatland, spokeswoman for Molson Coors Brewing (TAP). However, Hatland adds that long-term supply arrangements with farmers means Coors is less vulnerable to U.S. barley prices swings.   When Carlsberg (CARL-A.Denmark) released its results, chief executive Nils Andersen said he didn't think the higher prices were a trend and that the crop problems seen in 2006 probably wouldn't recur in 2007. Even though Anderson considers global warming to be a threat in general, he expects a more normal summer this year. "Then, the prices will go down," he says.   French agricultural analytical firm Strategie Grains says world barley output could rebound by 10 million tons in the coming season. E.U. barley fields are in good condition, but Rabobank's de Rijke notes this also was the case last season -- until summer heat zapped E.U. production.   Analysts say that, even with favorable weather, it will take about1 1 1/2 to 2 seasons to rebuild the extremely tight world supplies.   Raw materials account for about 20% of total costs for Heineken. Barley currently accounts for 6% of a beer's sale price, while packaging accounts for about  14%, according to Netherlands-based analyst Gerard Rijk at ING Barings.   With the costs of aluminum, glass and energy also on the rise, Rijk says brewers will need to raise beer prices 1.5% to 2% in the coming year. Obviously, consumers won't be toasting that possibility.     Nymex's Comex copper rose to a new high for the year on continuing expectations for strong global demand. Markets were closed Friday for Good Friday. The May contract closed Thursday at $3.3770 a pound, up 29.05 cents from the level a week earlier.   ---   Lisa Kallal is a reporter for Dow Jones Newswires in London   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Barron's Mailbag: Missing Hero
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     I cannot fathom why the greatest homebuilding CEO who ever lived, Robert Toll, dropped off your list ("The World's Best CEOs," Cover Story, March 26). Under Robert Toll's leadership, Toll Brothers became the first and still only nationwide home-buiding brand. And the brand has not been diminished at all during the current home-building downturn.   Toll Brothers has the best earnings-per-share and cash-flow "growth" among the publichome builders  the last four quarters (all home builders are negative). Toll Brothers' gross and operating margins remain the best in category over the same period.   Since the 2006 Best CEO list was published, the U.S. home-building business has gone from supercharged to wet firecracker. But the prescient and self-confident leadership of Bob Toll has grown from outstanding to superior. Toll Brothers did not get caught out with excessive land or spec-home inventory.   Lawrence Anvik   Guilford, Conn.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: YouTube In Talks With Thailand Over Clips That Mocked King
Story: BANGKOK (AP)--Popular video-sharing Web site YouTube and the Thai government are discussing ways to end an impasse that arose after clips mocking the country's revered king appeared online, a Thai official said Saturday.   Sitthichai Pookaiyaudom, the minister of information and technology, said the government would only remove its ban on the site once it has the technical capacity to block individual offensive pages.   "I am waiting to hear from (YouTube) about what can be done," Sitthichai told The Associated Press. "If YouTube can't suggest a solution that we can effectively implement, then we have no choice but to keep the ban."   Thailand blocked YouTube on Wednesday after its owner, Google Inc. (GOOG), refused to remove a slideshow of King Bhumibol Adulyadej juxtaposed with imagery deemed to be offensive.   Insulting the monarchy in Thailand is a criminal offense known as lese majeste. Last week, a Swiss man was imprisoned for 10 years for vandalizing portraits of the king.   After the site was blocked, several more videos mocking Thailand's revered king appeared on YouTube. Some of the new postings explicitly criticized the censorship of the first video.   YouTube said one of its representatives has spoken with Sitthichai directly and that the ministry's technical team is having difficulty understanding how to block individual videos.   "While we will not take down videos that do not violate our policies, and will not assist in implementing censorship, we have offered to educate the Thai Ministry about YouTube and how it works," said Julie Supan, head of global communications for YouTube.   Meanwhile, Sitthichai said that the site will remain blocked until all the contentious clips are removed.   "I am a proponent of free speech but this is just culturally insensitive and offensive," he said, adding that he wouldn't block access to materials that are anti-government. "But we will not tolerate materials that offend the monarchy."   He also said that the ministry remained concerned about the difficulty of blocking new materials that appeared almost daily.   "Pulling down individual clips is not effective since they could repost them," he said.   The initial video, which was withdrawn Thursday, showed pictures of feet over the king's head - a major cultural taboo in Thailand, where feet are considered dirty and offensive - and graffiti scrawled over the 79-year-old monarch's face. At least one still frame from the video remained on the site.   A variation of the withdrawn video reappeared Friday, along with a new one that showed a picture of the king superimposed with a monkey's face. It also carried messages with profanities and said that Thailand's "leaders are evil and hate free speech."   The YouTube ban has drawn sharp reactions in Thailand.   Some have criticized the ban as a violation of freedom of expression and another sign of censorship by the military-installed government that took power after a coup ousted former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra.   Many viewers, however, have reacted with outrage, hurling abuse at the clip's creator. Some newspaper columnists have praised the ban, saying that YouTube should respect cultural sensitivities and not allow videos that would be considered illegal in Thailand.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 02:32 ET (06:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Politics To Delay Ship Merger Of BAE, VT Group - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The GBP1 billion merger of BAE Systems PLC (BAESY) and VT Group PLC's (VTG.LN) shipbuilding assets has become a victim of politics and is likely to be delayed by several months, The Times reported Saturday, citing sources close to the government.   The creation of a single U.K. shipbuilder is being tied to an order by the Ministry of Defence for two aircraft carriers, each worth about GBP2 billion, the newspaper said.   Having missed a deadline to make the announcement last week, the news may be delayed until June or July to allow Gordon Brown to make the announcement as prime minister, assuming that he succeeds to the post, the newspaper reported.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 44 (0)20 7842-9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 05:51 ET (09:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Follow-Up: Petsmart Unleashed
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   Give Fido a bone and yourself a treat if you own shares of PetSmart.   Last fall ("Kibbles 'n' Ritz," Oct. 2), we reported favorably on PetSmart (ticker: PETM) after we visited its PetsHotel in Secaucus, N.J., and were impressed with the roaring faux fireplace, friendly staff and hypoallergenic lambskin blankets provided to the cuddly guests. Since then, the stock is up 21%, to 33.62.   It isn't check-out time yet, as Pet-Smart -- already No. 1 in retail sales of pet food and supplies -- plans lots of hotel openings to cash in on the pet-services boom. "There's another 20%" upside, says Ken Stuzin, co-manager of Brown Investment Advisory & Trust's Growth Equity Fund and holder of PetSmart shares. He adds that the stock, which ran into some volatility on recent news of tainted pet food, could reach 40 in 12 months.   Stuzin agrees with the consensus estimate that PetSmart will earn $1.66 a share in its year ended January 2008, but he sees $1.97 in the following year, a dime above the consensus. PetSmart made $1.33 per diluted share in fiscal '06.   Even if the economy slows, Stuzin says, more Americans, regardless of income, will treat their pets as people and "look at other places to cut" expenses.   So PetSmart should benefit from the new lifestyles of the pampered and furry.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: The -2-
Story: "Attracting and retaining talent is what we're all about," says Joe Amato, global head of asset management and a former high-yield analyst. "There's really nothing stopping our folks from walking across the street to another firm. It's incumbent on us to build, maintain and enhance the environment."   Neuberger also must replace key managers as they retire. But Schwartz, 65, notes that the Straus Group alone has six experienced managers, including one in his 40s and several in their 50s "who are full chiefs in making investment decisions."   The group oversees nearly $22 billion, two-thirds of it for wealthy individuals, compared with just $21 million when Schwartz became a partner in 1966. That growth was fueled by talent, good management and a culture that should endure -- as long as Lehman continues to show the good sense to leave it unchanged.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from March 30 through April 4. Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Youbet.com (UBET)   New World Opportunity Partners I may seek representation on the company's board. If it does, it may nominate Jay R. Pritzkeras a director. New World Opportunity Partners I holds 3,914,143 shares (9.3% of the total outstanding).     Idaho General Mines (GMO)   Shareholder Coghill Capital Management said it had notified Idaho General Mines of possible business combinations that it believes may be of interest to the company. Coghill also asked Idaho General's board to develop a plan to "achieve the highest quartile of corporate governance within the next six months." Coghill has 15.5 million shares (27.4%).     World Air Holdings (WLDA)   Riley Investment Management wants the company to be sold or go private. Riley said it is concerned about World Air's financial controls, late public filings, allocation of shareholder capital and its board's "lack of oversight and diligence" and absence of shareholder representation. Riley Investment owns about 1.42 million shares (5.9%).     Brink's (BCO)   MMI Investments remains "frustrated" over the company's "longstanding, significant undervaluation, relative to its peers" and called for a tax-free spinoff of Brink's two business segments. MMI believes the spinoff would result in an aggregate value of $79 a share for the two companies. MMI holds about four million shares (8.3%).     FSI International (FSII)   Chapman Capital intends to solicit interest in acquiring the company by prospective strategic buyers and to recruit personnel who would replace the current management. Chapman has become "increasingly disconcerted by the apparent divergence between ownership and management" of the Minneapolis maker of capital equipment for the microelectronics industry. Chapman holds about 1.99 million shares (6.5%).     American Bank Note Holographics (ABHH)   An investor group including Levy, Harkins & Co. said it had nominated five candidates for election to the board: Randall C. Bassett, J. Patrick Collins, Eric Haskell, David F. Waguespack and Peter Woodward. The group wants the new directors to consider a possible sale of American Bank Note Holographics. The group reported holdings of about 3.96 million shares (20.9%).     Increases in Holdings     Mueller Water Products (MWAB)   Fairholme Capital Management raised its stake to 9,524,500 Class B common shares (11.1%), by buying 1,475,500 from Jan. 29 to March 30 at $13.42 to $15.16 each.     NetManage (NETM)   Riley Investment Management raised its position to 668,752 shares (7%) from the 536,111 reported on Feb. 6. No transaction details were provided.     Decreases in Holdings     Orthovita (VITA)   Angiotech Pharmaceuticals (ANPI) sold all of the 5.68 million shares it owned on March 27. No details of the transaction were disclosed.     United Stationers (USTR)   Noonday Asset Management cut its stake to 2,130,000 shares (7.2%) by selling 604,889 from March 14 to April 2, at prices ranging from $57.12 to $60.13.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Malaysia's Proton Says No Tie-Up Preference Between VW, GM
Story: KUALA LUMPUR (AP)--Malaysia's national auto maker Proton Holdings Bhd. (5304.KU) said Saturday it had no preference between Europe's Volkswagen AG (VOW.XE) and U.S. auto maker General Motors Corp. (GM) for a strategic alliance, and that the government was still looking at both proposals, a news report said.   "The main issue is that the government and the country's objectives should be met," the national news agency Bernama quoted Proton managing director Syed Zainal Abidin as saying.   Malaysian state investment company Khazanah Nasional owns 43% of loss-making Proton, which has seen its market share in the Southeast Asian nation dwindle in the past few years.   The government has already missed a March deadline to decide between General Motors and Volkswagen.   Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, who is also finance minister, said recently he would meet Volkswagen executives, but didn't say when or provide any details.   Syed Zainal didn't say when a decision on a partnership would be made, and didn't say which auto maker was better suited for Proton.   "I think all stakeholders understand the importance" of the strategic partner, Bernama quoted him as saying. "We are working on the deadline but the decision is not a simple matter."   Proton, which hopes to become a significant exporter of cars, reported a net loss of 281.5 million ringgit (US$80 million) in the quarter that ended Dec. 31, 2006, compared with a net profit of MYR86.5 million a year earlier.   For years, the company thrived in a protected environment, including high duties on imported vehicles that forced many Malaysians to buy Proton cars. But the duties have been slowly lowered in line with a regional trade agreement, and more Malaysians have sought out imported vehicles.   In March, GM chief executive Rick Wagoner said there was still a lot of work to be done on a possible partnership, while Volkswagen executives said talks were at an advanced stage.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 04:17 ET (08:17 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) DC Current: The Discreet Charms Of Sallie Mae
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jim McTague   As the democrats' political fortunes began to visibly rise last summer, the shares of student-loan giant SLM, or Sallie Mae, went into a swoon. Democrats for years have been agitating for a reduction in arguably generous federal guarantees and subsidies paid to private lenders in the student-loan market -- and Sallie Mae is the biggest of the bunch. Since July, its shares (ticker: SLM) have fallen from the low 50s to a recent 41. But there's a compelling argument that theshares have been oversold, and could bounce back by at least 10%.   Virginia-based Sallie Mae, once a federally chartered corporation, went completely private in 2004, and now sports a market value or more than $17 billion. It makes both government-backed and private loans, issues loan guarantees and bundles loans for sale to investors as securities.   Ever since the administration of Bill Clinton, Democrats have treated lenders participating in the Federal Family Education Loan Program -- which dates to Lyndon Johnson's presidency -- as if they were vampires feeding sordidly off of students and taxpayers. Sen. Ted Kennedy of Massachusetts, chairman of the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, is especially contemptuous. He has called Sallie Mae a "sham." Its congressional foes seem to be out to vilify the industry in order to make their colleagues and the public more amenable to laws to weaken FFELP.   When Clinton was president, Kennedy and his allies passed a law that permitted the Department of Education to make loans directly to college students. The assumption was that DoE would dominate the market by being less costly and more efficient than private lenders like Sallie Mae, driving them out of this business. Instead, DoE's program, wrapped in the usual bureaucratic red tape, lost money. Some private lenders out-hustled it, offering better service.   A few lenders, it now appears, wined and dined officials at the universities who compliantly pushed their products. Andrew Cuomo, the man who replaced the relentless corruption-hound Eliot Spitzer as New York's attorney general, seems to have uncovered widespread evidence of this questionable style of courtship, including gifts of stock options to university and federal officials by Student Loan Xpress, owned by CIT Group (CIT).   When the Democrats assumed control of the House of Representatives in January, they passed a measure by a vote of 356 to 71 to cut subsidies to lenders by some $7.5 billion through 2012. There's a companion bill in the Senate co-sponsored by Kennedy awaiting action. Shares dropped from around $48 to $45. Then on Feb. 5, President Bush released his budget, which called for a sharp reduction in the interest rates Sallie Mae and other lenders are permitted to charge for student loans. This was unexpected; Bush had been an ally of the industry. Sallie Mae's shares dropped again, to around 42.   Sallie Mae's chairman, Albert Lord, had sold 400,000 shares of stock on Feb. 1 and 2, at about 46. Democrats in the House immediately launched an investigation to determine if Lord had any advance knowledge of the Bush budget, something Lord denies. Lord would not elaborate, because it turns out there's also a probe of the sale by the Securities and Exchange Commission.   The thunder and lightening set off by those investigations has discouraged contrarians from jumping in and buying the stock. The mortgage-market meltdown and the slowing economy also have investors worried that Sallie Mae might have to increase its writeoffs for bad loans.   The investigations on the Hill were started in part because Lord occasionally plays golf with House Republican Leader John Boehner of Ohio and in part because Sallie Mae's in-house lobbyist, Tim Morrison, once worked with Josh Bolten, now the White House chief of staff. The SEC may have felt compelled to launch an investigation so as not to be upstaged by Congress.   Lord advised his board of the pending sale on Jan. 25. Sallie Mae's officers and directors have a window of 30 days each quarter, following the release of earnings, when they may sell stock. He still owns 785,994 shares, worth about $32 million   Children, of course, are still heading off to college and borrowing heavily for tuition. The current consensus is that Sallie Mae will report earnings of close to 80 cents a share this quarter, and around $3.25 for the year. That means the stock is trading for a modest 13 times forward earnings. It used to trade at around 19 times forward earnings.   With just a bit of good news, the stock easily could pop toward 15 times earnings, or over 48. And what might that good news be? Because Democrats have just a slight advantage in the Senate, it's probable that Congress will give lenders a shave, not a scalping, when all is said and done. And Sallie Mae has seen the handwriting on the wall. We expect that the company will set a new course that isn't as dependent on federally subsidized loans.   ---   E-mail: jim.mctague@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: Searching From Sea To Sea For Value
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Neil A. Martin   Interview with John Buckingham   Chief Investment Officer, Al Frank Asset Management     John Buckingham wears many, well, caps. Working from offices overlooking the Pacific in beautiful Laguna Beach, Calif., he's both the chief exec and chief stockpicker for Al Frank Asset Management, a firm that roams freely from micro- to large-capitalization stocks in search of bargains, regardless of size or style. He and his team pore over 1,200 equities, searching for candidates for two mutual funds and separately managed accounts, with assets totaling $860 million. Buckingham also publishes the monthly Prudent Speculator investment newsletter, which, over three decades, has recommended 1,346 stocks that have enjoyed an average annual return of 20.61%. The Al Frank Fund (ticker: VALUX) has provided a nearly 16% annual return since its founding in 1998, a performance that puts it among the top 90 mutual funds over that span. A sister fund, Al Frank Dividend Value (VALDX), invests in inexpensive stocks that pay a dividend. We recently asked Buckingham, 41, about his market view and current favorites.     Barron's: In your recent newsletters and commentaries, you've sounded pretty optimistic about the stock market. What's so enticing?   Buckingham: I am always bullish on the long-term prospects of the undervalued stocks we own. And why not? Not only has history shown that equities in general have returned 10% to 12% per annum, on average, over the past eight decades, but value-priced stocks [trading at relatively low price-to-book-value ratios] have performed even better.     Q: Do you think stocks are still cheap?   A: Yes, I do. If you look at the big three equity benchmarks from Standard & Poor's, the large-cap S&P 500 now shows a 2007 forward price-earnings [P/E] ratio of 17.3, the mid-cap S&P 400 sports a forward P/E ratio of 17.4 and the small-cap S&P 600 boasts a forward P/E ratio of 18.2. All of these multiples are low by the standards of the past two decades, though I concede that they have certainly been lower over the past 80 years. Of course, interest rates are also unusually low, meaning that stocks should trade for higher valuations.     Q: Ok, but there are some disturbing signs, especially in the housing market, that the economy may be slowing, which would not be good for the market, correct?   A: Obviously, the U.S. economy is a wild card, but we think that the Federal Reserve has done, and will continue to do, a pretty good job of balancing growth and inflation.   We also can't forget that we're now in the seasonally-favorable third year of a presidency, a period that has been very positive for stocks in general and our shop in particular. Our newsletter model portfolios have had an average return of 52% for these years. In addition, though the Al Frank Fund did not commence operations until the start of 1998, its presidential third years -- 1999 and 2003 -- were its best ever, with gains of 60% and 78%, in that order.     Q: Your investment style has been described as all-cap-go-anywhere. Is that a fair characterization?   A: Nothing sets us apart more than our approach to selecting stocks, perhaps because we've never understood the industry's desire to be boxed in. It's our contention that limiting our investment possibilities by market capitalization or value-versus-growth distinctions only serves to limit our returns. Freeing ourselves with this style-agnostic mindset enables us to go forth and seek bargains wherever they may hide.   If small-cap stocks have had a great run, which is presently the case, it's time to start looking at mid- and large-cap companies. If a $100 million tech stock with a cash-rich balance sheet is inexpensive, we have no anti-tech bias that's going to preclude us from buying it. If a $100 billion financial behemoth with a single-digit P/E is on sale, we're buying. Bargains are bargains, and we'll be there to take advantage of them.     Q: What constitutes a bargain?   A: We search far and wide for stocks that are trading at substantial discounts -- 40% to 50% or more -- to our determination of their long-term, three-to-five-year fair-valuation price. Our target prices are based on a variety of factors, including financial fundamentals, historical norms, growth prospects and industry trends.     Q: What would be an example of this go-anywhere approach to investing?   A: If you look at our percentage weightings in Morningstar style boxes, you'll see that while the small-cap value box may be the largest category by weighting, it's by no means our exclusive target. And a holdings-based analysis of VALUX would reveal that the stocks in which we invest are generally less expensive than those pursued by our peers, while having greater growth characteristics. Who says a value manager can't invest in companies that grow?   For an even more vivid example of our go-anywhere style, consider the 10 stocks that have contributed the most to the performance of VALUX so far in 2007. They are large-caps Valero Energy (VLO), CSX (CSX) and US Steel (X); mid-caps Tesoro (TSO) and Goodyear Tire (GT); small-caps OMI (OMM) and Ryerson (RYI); and micro-caps LMI Aerospace (LMIA), Network Equipment Tech (NWK) and Vicon Industries (VII). [The Al Frank Fund currently owns about 300 stocks].     Q: What sectors do you like now?   A: We let valuations dictate the sectors in which we invest, and we strive to obtain exposure to as many industry groups as possible. But bargains have tended to congregate in sectors like materials, energy, business services and computing hardware.     Q: How about tech?   A: Unlike many of our value-oriented peers, we do find tremendous opportunity in technology. In fact, VALUX has had a significant tech weighting since its inception, yet it managed to avoid much of the fallout from the bursting of the tech bubble in 2000-2002. Believe it or not, our tech-heavy fund was actually up 7% in 2000 and up 30% in 2001. Generally speaking, we like to invest in technology companies where the balance sheet is strong; that is, with little or no long-term debt and lots of cash.     Q: Like what?   A: Among the large-cap stocks, we like Microsoft (MSFT). The company is a cash machine. We expect gains in the software giant's fortunes should soon begin to accelerate as the new Vista operating system and Office productivity-software cycles take hold, its next-generation server product hits the market and its Entertainment and Devices division, which includes the fantastic Xbox video-gaming unit, evolves toward a profit-contributing foundation. Microsoft trades for an inexpensive [for this company and its industry] 17 times forward earnings, yields 1.4% -- and the long-term-debt-free balance sheet shows $29 billion in cash and investments.     Q: What about medium and small companies?   A: Cypress Semiconductor (CY) is a very profitable, medium-sized integrated-circuit maker that owns about three-quarters of alternative-energy fave SunPower (SPWR). Its shares (52 million) in the solar-cell and solar-panel maker are worth almost $2.2 billion, yet the market-cap on all of Cypress is only $2.7 billion. Cypress' revenue, excluding SunPower, was $855 million in 2006, so there's more value than the market currently ascribes to it. Since we think the semiconductor and solar businesses both have great long-term growth potential, a purchase of Cypress affords an inexpensive way to play both trends.   Small-cap American Science & Engineering (ASEI) is a producer of X-ray inspection systems. It's a homeland- security play that trades for a market multiple, while having superb growth prospects and a pristine balance sheet that sports more than $12 per share in cash, net of debt.     Q: What do you like in energy?   A: We have been heavy into the energy sector with names like Giant Industries (GI), Marathon Oil (MRO) and TransOcean (RIG), joining the aforementioned Tesoro and Valero. And because we continue to believe that the global economies will remain healthy this year and next, as well as over the next five to 10 years, we remain fans of the energy sector, as valuations have hardly caught up with the tremendous earnings growth seen over the past few years, and in many instances, likely to be seen over the next few years.     Q: Who are your current favorites?   A: Large-cap Chesapeake Energy (CHK) is one. While natural gas, the lion's share of their business, has been extremely volatile, this company has done a terrific job of hedging their production in the past couple of years when prices were high, while scooping up properties in years past when prices were much lower. It presently trades for less than nine times earnings.   Rowan Cos. (RDC) is another. This medium-size contract oil-and-gas driller operates 21 shallow-water jack-up rigs and 26 land-based rigs. The company also builds rigs and mining equipment like front loaders. And it has a major cost advantage over other drillers, as it produces all of the steel it needs for equipment production in its own mini-mill. As a result, it does not to have to worry about potential steel-cost pressures. Rowan's shares currently change hands at about seven times the '07 consensus earnings forecast, with that number dropping to six on the '08 estimate.     Q: You were a big bull on housing. Is that still the case?   A: While the housing sector has hurt us in the past year or so, we have been in housing-related stocks since VALUX was launched in 1998, so we can't complain too much about our overall experience. We share the outlook of many homebuilders who expect the decline in national-housing activity in 2006 to be followed by another falloff in 2007 as the excess inventories of speculator-owned homes are sold to true home buyers. But we are optimistic that 2008 will see a stabilization or an increase in housing starts again. In the near-term, we would expect the flow of news to remain pretty depressing.     Q: Who do you like?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Printing Money
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Takeovers are changing the face of the newspaper-publishing business, a trend that will continue if Sam Zell's leveraged buyout of Tribune succeeds. As the deals pile up, Wall Street is starting to wonder what steps Gannett, the industry leader, might take to cheer its long-suffering shareholders.   Gannett's shares (ticker: GCI), now at 56, have fallen along with those of other newspaper operators in recent years as the company's profits have gone flat. Down from a peak of 90, the stock is back where it traded in 1998. Gannett's profits have been stuck at about $4.90 a share for the past three years, though this year's are expected to fall to $4.71, reflecting weak newspaper-advertising trends and a decline in political ads at the company's TV-broadcasting division in an off-election year. Recent advertising trends at Gannett and most publishers have been poor.   Gannett publishes USA Today, a large group of newspapers in small to midsized U.S. cities, and regional papers in Britain. Known for its strong financial management and cost controls, the McLean, Va.-based company has the highest operating margins in the U.S. newspaper business, at almost 30%. With a market value of $13.2 billion and debt of $5 billion, it is an unlikely target for a takeover or leveraged buyout, especially given private-equity firms' aversion to the industry.   Yet there are steps Gannett could take to enhance shareholder value, starting with a sizable increase in its annual dividend, now $1.24 a share, which provides a yield of 2.2% The company also could spin off its TV operation, which includes an attractive collection of NBC stations. Pure-play TV stocks like Lin TV (TVL) and Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) have doubled in the past six months, reflecting potential buyout interest and the prospect for increases in retransmission payments from cable operators for local stations.   Gannett gets little credit for its captive broadcast division, which generates 10% of its annual revenue and 17% of its pre-tax cash flow. Given rising valuations in the sector, the TV business could be worth $5 billion, or more than $20 per Gannett share. Other assets include a 42% stake in CareerBuilder.com, a leading online jobs site, that could be worth $600 million.   So far, Gannett's management, led by CEO Craig Dubow, 52, has been cool to the idea of a hefty dividend increase or TV spin-off. The company seems to want the financial flexibility to make acquisitions or expand its stock-buyback program. Dubow headed Gannett's broadcast unit before succeeding longtime CEO Doug McCorkindale in 2005, and may be reluctant to part with it.   A Gannett spokeswoman said last week that Gannett "considers any option that would enhance shareholder value. Our executives and board are very engaged in considering any and all options." Gannett executives declined to comment.   Gannett trades for 12 times estimated 2007 profits, the lowest price/earnings ratio in the newspaper group. Zell is paying $34 a share, or 17 times '07 forecasts, for Tribune (TRB). Stronger than Tribune, Gannett is expected to produce about $5 a share of free cash this year, resulting in a free-cash-flow yield of 9%, among the highest in the business.   Credit Suisse analyst Debra Schwartz, who upgraded Gannett to Outperform from Neutral this year, and set a $65 price target,wrote in a client note that a "significant potential catalyst" for the company's stock price would be the use of its "free cash." Although the company doesn't have an activist shareholder base, she said management is "under pressure to improve returns."   Late last year Merrill Lynch analyst Lauren Rich Fine caused a stir when she wrote a client note titled "Deafening Dividend Drumbeat," in which she said "investors are becoming obsessed with Gannett's ability to pay a much higher dividend and its seeming reluctance to do so."   Gannett is paying out just 25% of its earnings and free cash flow, but could easily lift its annual dividend to $3 or $3.50 a share -- and probably more than $4. With a dividend of $3.50, Gannett would yield more than 6%, and still have ample cash for other initiatives, including the transformation of its newsrooms into "information centers" to serve both print and online readers.   Gannett's problem may be that management still views newspaper publishing as a growth business, rather than the mature --  or declining -- pursuit it has become. Investors in mature industries like high dividends to offset the inherent business risk.   The bear case for Gannett, and other publishers, is that corporate advertising and high-margin classifieds will continue to migrate to the Internet. Skeptics argue Gannett's plump margins will fall. But the company's focus on small to mid-sized markets and its obsession with local coverage may help insulate it from the woes affecting big-city papers like the Boston Globe.   Historically a buyer of newspapers, Gannett has been a restrained acquirer in recent years, even refusing to bid for Knight-Ridder last summer. Knight-Ridder's buyer, McClatchy (MNI), has seen its shares plunge 40% since the deal, by far the worst showing in the industry.   In 2004 and 2005, Gannett had an aggressive share-buyback program, repurchasing more than 37 million or 13% of its shares. The purchases were badly timed, costing the company an average of $80 a share. Viewed another way, Gannett wasted $900 million of shareholder money that could have been used to lift the dividend. The dividend issue is timely since New York Times' (NYT) announcement last month that it would increase its payout by 31%, for a yield of nearly 4%.   On Gannett's earnings conference call in February, the company showed little interest in a higher dividend. CFO Gracia Martore said: "We continue to look for significant examples where companies that have dramatically increased their dividend have seen a long-term, even intermediate to long-term, benefit to their stock price."   But Gannett may be missing the example of Gatehouse Media (GHS), a leveraged operator of small-market newspapers that went public in late 2006. Formed and controlled by Fortress Investment Group (FIG), Gatehouse trades at 20 and yields 7%; the company pays out nearly all its free cash in dividends. Result:  it's  valued at 13 times projected 2007 pre-tax cash flow, a 60% premium to Gannett.   Gannett doesn't have to be so generous, but its current dividend policy seems stingy. Given the challenges in the industry, it might have to rethink its conservative financial and corporate strategy. Unlike New York Times, Dow Jones (DJ, the publisher of Barron's) and Washington Post (WPO), Gannett doesn't have a controlling family or super-voting stock. If the company doesn't move, it could attract activist investors who would seek to force change.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: The Village That Works
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   Wall Street firms have had mixed results in the asset-management business. Citigroup and Merrill Lynch, with their vast retail brokerage forces, got out, thanks partly to potential conflicts over peddling in-house funds to clients. Mediocre performance didn't help either. Morgan Stanley is trying to fix its asset-management unit, which has been plagued by underperformance and outflows in recent years.   But Lehman Brothers (ticker: LEH) has done much better, in part because of one smart deal -- the 2003 purchase of Neuberger Berman, just as the U.S. equity market was starting to revive. Value stocks, then as now, were often the winners, a trend that has played neatly to Neuberger Berman's strengths.   Lehman bought the venerable money manager for about $2.5 billion in stock and cash. Neuberger now supervises about $121 billion, accounting for a little more than half of Lehman's asset-management business, which on Feb. 28 stood at $236 billion.   Neuberger's assets have roughly doubled since mid-2003, as has Lehman's stock price, which was north of 70 late last week. Lehman, which doesn't have a mass-market retail-brokerage unit, does have distribution muscle in an important and growing market -- wealthy investors -- along with capital, and an esteemed management team led by longtime Chief Executive Richard S. Fuld.   Also, Lehman, whose investment-management division accounted for about $2.4 billion, or 13.7%, of the firm's overall revenue last year, now has a more stable earnings stream, in part because of the fees generated from managing a lot more money, including fixed-income investments and stakes in alternative investments such as private-equity holdings. Prior to 2003, it had a very small asset-management business.   While its asset totals are dwarfed by those of behemoth mutual-fund firms like Capital Research and Management, Fidelity and Vanguard, all of which oversee around $1 trillion, Neuberger Berman remains an effective niche player, in part because Lehman has trod relatively lightly. "There has been no interference, nor any indication of a desire to mess around with the management of the assets," Jack Rivkin, Neuberger's veteran chief investment officer, tells Barron's.   Notes Marvin C. Schwartz, a longtime money manager who works at the Straus Group, a Neuberger unit: "Lehman said we are going to continue to support your research department and commissions you are paying to Wall Street firms."   Lehman has not only retained the Neuberger brand but has expanded it. Neuberger's most public accounts, its equity retail mutual funds, now total $34 billion. The firm, based in its own Manhattan digs separate from Lehman's headquarters, offers a range of no-load equity funds (although some charge 12b-1 fees), many with a value bent.   The managers emphasize fundamental research, and investing with conviction. "They are definitely not index-huggers," says David Kathman, an analyst at Morningstar who gives the firm a good overall grade for its investment approach.   Neuberger Berman was launched in 1939 by Roy Neuberger and Robert Berman. Berman died in the 1950s; Neuberger, who is 103 and no longer actively involved with the firm, was trading stocks in the 1920s. Known as a renaissance man with a deep understanding of money management, Neuberger cut a big figure in modern art and philanthropy.   Besides being a savvy investor, he knew how to build a business. In the 1950s and 1960s, when $100,000 was a big account, he and his partners, including Phil Straus, focused on managing money for wealthy clients. In the 1970s, when the pension-fund world opened to new investment talent owing to federal legislation, Neuberger ventured there, too. The firm is still known for catering to the wealthy, its $52 billion in institutional equity assets notwithstanding.   Neuberger's reputation for investment acumen dates to its founding.   In the late 1940s, Alfred Winslow Jones, widely regarded as having launched the first hedge fund, turned to Neuberger Berman for prime-brokerage services. Jones "went to every leading investment-banking firm, and when they heard that a basic tenet of portfolio management was going to be selling stocks short, they didn't want anything to do with it," says Schwartz, who joined the Straus Group in 1961.   In the 1950s, Neuberger further solidified its reputation by providing research on the burgeoning electric-utilities industry. Toward the end of that decade, it helped its clients with a good call on AT&T. "Neuberger got wind that very, very good things were going to happen there," Schwartz recalls. "And almost every single account at the firm loaded up."   A strong commitment to research still pervades Neuberger, which has a centralized team with 42 employees, up from 28 when Rivkin joined the company in 2002. In addition, some of the investment teams have their own research staffs -- and they can tap Lehman's bench of sell-side analysts. "We make tremendous use of it," says Schwartz.   At Neuberger's headquarters, a daily ritual is the morning meeting, held at 8:15.   On a recent day, Teresa Donahue, a veteran retail analyst with more than a decade at Neuberger, weighed in on Tiffany (TIF), which in her view still has upside. Maureen McGrath, a former sell-side analyst, addressed the issue du jour: the fallout of the deteriorating subprime residential mortgage market. Her take: The market has discounted the news -- although she doesn't expect a U.S. housing recovery until next year.   "If you're going to have any credibility with the portfolio managers, you're going to have to speak their language," Rivkin, himself a former analyst, tells a reporter after the meeting. "It's not that you can't have uncertainty, but you always have to reach a conclusion."   Neuberger has plenty of clout with brokerage firms, owing to its large volume of stock trading. It also doesn't have trouble luring corporate executives to discuss their companies' outlooks. On average, Rivkin says, six companies visit its New York or Chicago offices every day.   In overseeing the operation, Rivkin, a fly-fishing enthusiast who's been around Wall Street since the 60s, eschews making short-term market predictions.
