Instead, he tries to make sure his investment teams are thinking about the "big themes," such as the growth of China, the aging global population and alternative energy. "If you get the right calls on those issues, the wind is at your back," Rivkin says.   Even though Neuberger is known as a value shop, Rivkin oversees a disparate group of managers whose styles can differ, sometimes crossing over to growth. There is no mandatory, firmwide Buy or Sell list. One analyst calls Neuberger "a village of boutiques."   Guy Moszkowski, who covers Lehman for Merrill Lynch, says the structure is "a plus and a minus." In his view, "it's probably harder to manage an organization that's diverse like that. But, on balance, it's been a strength."   Rivkin, helped by the portfolio analytics group, keeps tabs on 40-plus investment teams, more than 25 of which specialize in high-net-worth accounts, monitoring everything from price-earnings multiples to how much of a fund's return resulted from stock selection or sector bets. The teams include the Straus Group, which looks for undervalued securities, and the Kaminsky Group, whose strategy is considered opportunistic growth and income. Seventeen other teams focus on institutional money.   The Neuberger mutual funds generally have good long-term track records; however, with managers unafraid to make contrarian calls, they can strike out sometimes. One example is Neuberger Berman Genesis (NBGAX), helmed by longtime managers Judith Vale and Robert W. D'Alelio and closed to new investors. Its one-year return of 6.59% ranks in the 46th percentile of its Morningstar peer group, small-cap blend. However, its three-year (13.29%) and five-year (13.06%) numbers are in the top 30%.   The managers hew to a buy-and-hold philosophy, and they'll let their winners run. "We have always run money the same way, which is to buy high-quality companies at reasonable prices," says Vale.   Concerned that the economy is slowing, Vale and her team have steered the $10.4 billion portfolio away from cyclical areas, although it still has a healthy dose of energy. She reduced its number of financial stocks while boosting the overall total of holdings to more than 140. Both changes were made to reduce risk. The fund's pullback from cyclicality, Vale says, "penalized us last year, but it's helping this year."   Other retail funds in the firm's stable include Neuberger Berman Focus (NBSSX), a sometimes volatile large-cap blend offering, run by Robert Cormanes. Its three-year annual return, a paltry 2.35%, trails the S&P 500's by nearly eight percentage points and ranks near the bottom of its Morningstar peer group, although Morningstar's Kathman credits Corman for reducing the fund's volatility.   A fund with a stronger recent track record is Neuberger Berman Guardian (NBGUX), a large-cap blend portfolio whose lead manager is Arthur Moretti. Other funds in the lineup include Neuberger Berman Partners (NBPBX), which S. Basu Mullick oversees by looking for undervalued companies with a long-term investment horizon.   Overall, Neuberger's retail funds earn plaudits. Their expenses have fallen since Lehman took over, Kathman says, and the firm seems to understand the concept of being a fiduciary. For example, it closed the Neuberger Berman International Fund (NBITX), a well-regarded portfolio that Benjamin Segal has run since 2000, because of worries about whether it had become too big.   For all of its success, Neuberger isn't immune to trouble. Non-compete agreements for various managers, in place since the Lehman acquisition, will begin to expire, probably starting next year. With genuine money-management talent at a premium amid an abundance of liquidity, Neuberger must guard against raids.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barclays Closes In On ABN Amro Takeover - FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Barclays PLC (BARC.LN) is expected to unveil its takeover of ABN Amro Holding NV (ABN) within the next 10 days as executives at the two banks hammer out the final details of what is likely to be the largest ever financial services deal, the Financial Times reported Saturday, citing people familiar with the matter.   Barclays and ABN Amro have made good progress in estimating the cost savings and revenue benefits likely to flow from the cash-and-shares deal, the newspaper said, which would create an institution worth more than $175 billion.   Executives are expected to argue that the combined bank will be able to boost its revenue growth by selling Barclay's investment banking and fund management products to the Dutch bank's 25 million customers, the newspaper reported.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 44 (0)20 7842-9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 04:47 ET (08:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: -2-
Story: A: We like home-improvement retailer Home Depot (HD), which has suffered the wrath of shareholders disgusted with recent growth rates and previous management's cavalier attitude. The stock is about as cheap as it has ever been, trading for 13 times earnings while yielding more than 2%. We also like D.R. Horton (DHI), one of the biggest homebuilders, with operations in more than 25 states and a two-decade-plus history of tremendous growth. It's expected to remain solidly profitable, and is forecast to earn $1.67 in its fiscal year ending next September, $1.82 in 2008 and $2.63 in 2009.     Q: Are you worried that the subprime mess will spill into your housing picks?   A: We have had to pull back our target prices for all of our housing stocks on subprime concerns, but we don't think the damage will spread significantly in the short run. We expect the housing sector to rebound over our three-to-five-year time horizon.   That's why we are staying with mid-cap player [IndyMac Bancorp] (NDE), a hybrid thrift/mortgage banker and the seventh-largest U.S. savings and loan. FDIC-insured deposits represent 42% of borrowings -- making its funding sources far more diversified than all those bankrupt subprime lenders and mortgage REITs that have relied on the big banks and Wall Street for financing.   The company maintains an investment-grade rating and had loan production in 2006 of $91.7 billion, a 48% increase over 2005. Perhaps most importantly, subprime loans make up only 4% of overall loan production. The stock now has a higher dividend yield (6.7%) than P/E ratio (6.2).     Q: You're a big fan of dividends, correct?   A: Yes, we are a big fan of undervalued stocks that pay dividends. Particular dividend stocks we like include large-cap pharmaceutical giant Pfizer (PFE), one of the few drug stocks yet to be let out of the dog house. It now trades for an incredibly low P/E of 12, while yielding 4.6% and offering an excellent long-term demographics play.   We also find attractive small-caps like oil tanker operator Tsakos Energy (TNP), which yields 5.4% and trades for nine times the current '07 EPS estimate. It boasts a modern fleet of vessels. Finally, we're fond of United Online (UNTD), an Internet-service provider trading for 13 times '07 EPS estimates, owns a balance sheet that's virtually debt-free with roughly $2.50 in cash per share and yields 5.7%.     Q: Ever thought about starting a hedge fund?   A: We are always working to improve our research methodologies, and we can't rule out one day launching a hedge fund. But we intend to dance with what brought us this far -- the Al Frank Way, which has served us well for the two decades that I have been with the company. We take great pride that we have never wavered in our disciplined approach of buying and patiently holding a broadly diversified portfolio of undervalued stocks for their long-term appreciation potential.     Q: Good luck and thanks, John.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Crescent Announces Contract to Sell Resort Hotel Portfolio and Single Office Asset Reinstated
Story: FORT WORTH, Texas--(BUSINESS WIRE)--April 07, 2007--   Crescent Real Estate Equities Company (NYSE:CEI) announced today that on March 5, 2007, Crescent Real Estate Equities Limited Partnership, a Delaware limited partnership, and certain of its subsidiaries and affiliates, and Walton TCC Hotel Investors V, L.L.C., a Delaware limited liability company, had entered into a series of Purchase and Sale Agreements which were amended on March 23, 2007 effective as of March 5, 2007 pursuant to which, among other things, (a) the Sellers agreed to sell to the Purchaser all of the Sellers' rights, title and interest in the Fairmont Sonoma Mission Inn & Spa(R), the Sonoma Golf Club, the Ventana Inn & Spa(R), the Park Hyatt Beaver Creek Resort & Spa, the Omni Austin hotel and the Austin Center office building adjacent to the hotel, the Denver Marriott hotel and the Renaissance Houston hotel and (b) the Partnership agreed to guaranty certain obligations of the Sellers under the Original Purchase Agreement. The Original Purchase Agreement was terminated by the Purchaser on April 2, 2007 at the end of its due diligence period.     On April 6, 2007, the Sellers and the Purchaser reinstated and amended the Original Purchase Agreement. The total gross purchase price under the Purchase Agreement, which was determined through arm's length negotiations between the parties, is approximately $620 million. Crescent's share of the gross purchase price, determined after taking into account the interests of its partners in the sales and incentive payments due as a result of the sales, is approximately $580 million. The Purchaser has paid a nonrefundable earnest money deposit of approximately $11 million.     The closing of the transactions contemplated by the Purchase Agreement is subject to the satisfaction of certain customary closing conditions. There are no assurances that the conditions will be met or that the transaction will be consummated. The parties to the Purchase Agreement presently anticipate that the closing will occur during the second quarter of 2007. Neither Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, the sole shareholder of the general partner and the majority limited partner of the Partnership, nor the Partnership, nor any of the Sellers or any affiliate of the foregoing has a material relationship with Purchaser, other than pursuant to the Purchase Agreement.       ABOUT THE COMPANY     Crescent Real Estate Equities Company (NYSE: CEI) is a real estate investment trust headquartered in Fort Worth, Texas. Through its subsidiaries and joint ventures, Crescent owns and manages a portfolio of 71 premier office buildings totaling 28 million square feet located in select markets across the United States with major concentrations in Dallas, Houston, Austin, Denver, Miami, and Las Vegas. Crescent also holds investments in resort residential developments in locations such as Scottsdale, AZ, Vail Valley, CO, and Lake Tahoe, CA; in destination resorts such as Fairmont Sonoma Mission Inn(R) in Sonoma, CA; and in the wellness lifestyle leader, Canyon Ranch(R). For more information, visit Crescent's Web site at www.crescent.com.        CONTACT: Crescent Real Estate Equities Company               Jane E. Mody, 817-321-1086               Managing Director, Capital Markets               Or               Jeremy C. Sweek, 817-321-1464               Investor & Media Relations Senior Manager        SOURCE: Crescent Real Estate Equities Company  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 16:30 ET (20:30 GMT)

Headline: Turkish Airlines Net Profit Up 28% On Yr At $132M -IHA
Story: ISTANBUL (Dow Jones)--Turkey's national carrier Turkish Airlines (THYAO.IS) said late Friday its net profit rose 28% on the year to $132 million in 2006, the Ihlas News Agency, or IHA, reported Saturday.   The airline, also known as THY, said in a statement the rise in fuel prices in 2006 increased costs by $108 million from the year before.   However, despite rising oil prices, the company's pre-tax net profit climbed 3% year-on-year to $139 million in 2006 while its equity capital increased 12% to $1.145 billion in the same period.   Assets climbed 15% on the year to $3.272 billion in 2006 while its core operation income increased 22% to $2.832 billion in the same period.   The number of passengers rose 20% year-on-year to 17 million in 2006.   Previously, THY said it aimed to host 20 million passengers in 2007.   THY's fleet of planes reached 103 in 2006, and the company intends to add nine planes during the rest of this year and 19 planes next year.   The Turkish Privatization Agency sold a 23% stake in THY for $199 million and another 28.75% stake for $317 million in two separate public offerings in December 2004 and last May, respectively.   In November, Finance Minister Kemal Unakitan said the government's remaining stake in THY was still in the government's 2007 privatization plans.     Agency Web sites: http://www.ihavideo.net and http://www.iha.com.tr     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 07:32 ET (11:32 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(4/9) European Trader: Why Aeroflot Bid's A Bad Idea
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Arindam Nag   The planned bid for Alitalia by Aeroflot has long-term strategic logic, but if Aeroflot succeeds, it runs the risk of a financial misadventure that could set back its own recovery.   Aeroflot (AFLT.Russia), with a market value of roughly $3 billion, has shown strong signs of turning around in the last couple of years. It might even end its 2006 fiscal year with free cash flow of roughly $200 million. Its balance sheet has become stronger, with net debt amounting to roughly 0.25 times equity, a far cry from the nearly six times it was in 2001.   But this recovery could be in jeopardy quickly if the company goes ahead with its bid for Alitalia (AZA.Italy), even though Aeroflot isn't planning to buy all of Alitalia itself. The Russian carrier has secured the backing of Unicredit (UC.Italy) for its bid. Speculation is also growing that Air France-KLM (AF.France) might join the Aeroflot-led consortium if the Italian government permits the expansion of one of the investor groups in the auction for the carrier.   Even if Aeroflot settles for just slightly more than 50% ownership -- Uni- Credit is in for 5%, and Aeroflot might sell a bigger stake to Air France-KLM -- it will still consolidate Alitalia's financials with its own. It's certainly hard to imagine Aeroflot being interested in Alitalia without majority control.   But that would put the companies' combined debt at more $2 billion, supported by a combined Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, of $600 million, based on 2006 results. On average, airlines with similar profiles have lower leverage -- between two and three times Ebitda.   Some airlines have recovered with worse balance sheets in the past. US Airways (LCC) and UAL's (UA) United Airlines have shown such resilience, but they were also showing robust traffic growth.   Alitalia doesn't score well on this front. According to the Association of European Airlines, its passenger traffic grew 1.3% in 2006, way below the average 5.2%. Iberia's grew 7%, KLM's 5% and Air France's 6.4%   What Alitalia does offer Aeroflot is a quick way of attaining economies of scale, given that the Russian airline is much smaller than it was during the Soviet era. Much of Aeroflot's recovery plan has revolved around how quickly it would be allowed to acquire five domestic Russian airlines, which would boost annual passenger traffic to 30 million, similar to that of Lufthansa, for example.   Aeroflot needs to replace its aging fleet. It has announced a tender to buy 22 foreign-made planes to be delivered after 2008. That will attract Russia's heavy value-added tax and customs duties, increasing the cost of each aircraft by nearly 40% to 50% over list price.   Buying Alitalia solves the problem by putting its big fleet of underutilized aircraft at the disposal of Aeroflot, which would benefit from Alitalia's long-haul routes.   Yet the financial burden of Alitalia, given the operational challenges of turning the Italian carrier around, looks too onerous for Aeroflot to take on.   Consolidating its own domestic market at a time when the Russian economy is growing looks like a more sensible, if not necessarily easy option.   ---   ARINDAM NAG is a contributor to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column upon which this European Trader is based.   ---                       DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES     Region/   Country    DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point     Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: Barron's(4/9) Tech Trader: Here's How The Drama Over 'net Neutrality Ends
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   The Federal Communications Commission said last month that it would study 'Net Neutrality. But I will make the daring prediction that the debate over 'Net Neutrality is over. The argument arose as Websites like Google and Yahoo! drew swelling streams of traffic over the Internet. The Websites feared that phone or cable carriers would surcharge for the Websites' traffic flows, or else give speedier service to the carriers' own sites. So lobbyists for the Websites squared off against phone company lobbyists, and regulators and legislators considered 'Net Neutrality rules that would bar network service providers from charging extra for the electronic equivalent of express mail.   But now that Google (ticker: GOOG) owns YouTube, it will have to think about ways of funding the big pipes needed to get quality videos to its audience -- especially when those videos become high-definition. Video and voice streams suffer when their packets must fight Internet traffic jams. My family knows this. They hate the echoes and dropouts that have bedeviled their phone calls  since I put the house on a Voice-over-Internet-Protocol service.   That VoIP service, luckily, is not Vonage Holdings (VG), which a judge barred Friday from signing on new customers while it appeals a patent-infringement judgment. (Late in the day, Vonage won a temporary stay of the order.) Up in Canada, the cable firm Shaw Communications charges 10 bucks a month extra to guarantee priority transmission to customers of VoIP services like Vonage. It's just a matter of time before we Yanks decide that it's OK to pay a little extra to Verizon Communications (VZ) to get a decent show from an Internet site like Joost (whether the payment is a monthly subscription or part of the one-time cost of viewing).   If video and voice demands do shake loose new funding for first-class passage, are there stock plays? Of course there are the network arms merchants Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR). But there's a more specific way to play the undoing of 'Net Neutrality: a technology called Deep Packet Inspection, or DPI. Such gear lets carriers look inside the data packets that cross their network, to determine if the traffic is e-mail, video or voice. The network can then control its traffic, facilitating media flows and deprioritizing a BitTorrent node that's disseminating pirated Beatles music.   Many of the DPI vendors' sales  have been outside the U.S., where regulators worry less about treating all traffic equally. U.S. carriers have bought DPI devices, but mostly just to know what's happening on their wires. DPI's popularity, however, could leap if the U.S. phone and cable firms can use the gear to generate new revenue by selling special-delivery service for an Internet movie. Every big wireline and wireless carrier in the U.S. has a requisition out now for DPI gear, says Fred Sammartino, head marketer for the privately-held DPI seller Ellacoya Networks, of Merrimack, N.H.   The DPI opportunity was a long time coming, so there aren't that many competitors. The largest DPI vendor, it turns out, is Cisco. The giant networker acquired DPI supplier p-cube in 2004 for $200 million and so Cisco has an inside track on all those networks built from Cisco switches and routers. Ellacoya also has a shot at the big time, with a head start in delivering carrier-grade inspection gear that can keep up with a 10-gigabit flow of network traffic.   There are a couple of publicly-held DPI specialists, too. Sandvine is a Waterloo, Ontario, company that's listed on the Toronto exchange (SVC.TO). Many cable television customers like Comcast and some phone customers enabled Sandvine to double its revenue in the fiscal year ended November 2006, to 32 million Canadian dollars (US$28 million), and almost break even. It expects to reach sales of C$50 million to C$60 million in the November 2007 year. At a recent Toronto price of C$3.50, the company is valued at C$430 million.   But another DPI leader is selling at a bargain-basement price, after warning investors last week that its March quarter sales will fall short of expectations. Nasdaq-listed Allot Communications (ALLT) fell from above 9 to around 7, for a market value of about $145 million. Allot came public in November at $12 and finished 2006 with $34 million in revenue and four cents a share in earnings. It expected sales of almost $10 million in the March quarter, but admitted last Monday that they will probably fall below $8.3 million. Allot blamed its third-party distributors for the shortfall. Yet Allot says that it's doing fine in its direct sales to telecom carriers.   Investor relations head Jay Kalish told me that the company is a contender in many of the ongoing requisition plans, with a box Allot is developing that will run at 10 Gigabits a second, like Sandvine's. The product will be available when networks are ready to buy in the third quarter.   Meanwhile, Allot had more than $80 million in cash on its December balance sheet, so the disappointed stock market is really valuing the company at about $70 million. That's around 1.5 times this year's sales for Allot, compared with 7 times sales for Sandvine.   Cisco may get its big share of DPI installations, but there's plenty of non-Cisco infrastructure out there. Allot and Sandvine will surely get their share, too.   The once hot medical technology of drug-eluting stents got a blackeye at a recent cardiology conference when a large study reported that patients with stents in their heart arteries lived no longer than those who simply took their medicine. Boston Scientific (BSX) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) had previously seen a decline in sales of their drug-coated stents -- expensive little tubes that prop open heart arteries narrowed by atherosclerosis -- on evidence that they could occasionally cause dangerous blood clots. So Bruce Nudell, a Sanford Bernstein analyst, corralled a couple of Dartmouth professors and asked if the latest study would further dent stent demand. Not in the U.S., said the cardiologists, because American patients won't tolerate angina, the agonizing pain of an oxygen-starved heart muscle. Stents relieve angina. Drugs usually don't.   Still, one of Nudell's profs said he expected to move most of his stenting to the new Xience product from Abbott Laboratories (ABT) when it's approved. So Boston Scientific will remain a cheap stock until the company figures out its restructuring story.   ---   E-mail: william.alpert@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Germany's Fraport To Take 24.5% Stake In NW Chinese Airport
Story: BEIJING (AP)--Germany's Fraport AG (FRA.XE), operator of Frankfurt International Airport, will invest about EUR50 million for a 24.5% share in an airport in northwestern China, the company said.   The Frankfurt-based airport company signed an agreement Friday for the stake in Xi'an Airport in Shaanxi province, a statement on the company's Web site said.   The state-owned China West Airport Group, formerly the airport's sole owner, will retain the majority of shares, it said.   Fraport said it would take over the airport's commercial development and work on optimizing its operations.   The company expects to obtain approval from Chinese authorities and complete the transaction in the third quarter of this year, the statement said.   Xi'an Airport received 9.4 million passengers last year and that figure is expected to increase to 11 million this year, Fraport said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 01:20 ET (05:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) The Trader: Higher Rates May Give Stock Investors Pause
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   The main event didn't draw much of a crowd. The March employment report came in stronger than expected on Good Friday, when the stock markets were closed and bonds traded only in the morning. Employers added a robust 180,000 jobs during the month and the unemployment rate shrank to 4.4%.   The latest signal of economic health sent electronically traded S&P 500 futures higher on Friday by 5.3 points to 1458. However investors' enthusiasm Monday may be tempered by the bond markets' response. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note climbed to 4.75% and the yield curve flattened on dwindling expectations that the Federal Reserve will lower rates later this year.   "While the employment report was strong, I think the debate [about the economy's health] will continue," says David Ader, head of government-bond strategy at Greenwich Capital Markets.   Indeed, data from earlier in the week signaled a much weaker environment. Unemployment claims rose a bit, the ISM manufacturing index fell to just 50.9 and analysts' estimates for earnings growth continued to wane. Now Wall Street analysts are looking for 3.3% growth in the first quarter and 6.3% for the full year, down from 3.8% and 6.7% just a week earlier, according to Thomson Financial.   There will be a lot of statistics going in both directions amid weak economic growth, says Bob Doll, global chief investment officer of equities at BlackRock. But Doll continues to expect 5% earnings growth and 7% gains in the S&P 500 this year as booming exports more than offset the housing slowdown.   Last week the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed a bit more than 200 points in the four sessions to 12,560, returning to positive territory for the year. The S&P 500 added almost 23 points on the week to end at 1443.76, and the Nasdaq Composite jumped nearly 50 points to 2471.   Mergers and acquisitions keep generating throngs of excited participants no matter the market's direction. And they continue to provide a strong underpinning to stock prices. Last week bidding grew even more heated for the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler (DCX). Kirk Kerkorian stepped into an already crowded ring of bidders that includes Magna International (MGA) and Cerberus Capital Management, among others.   The news helped Daimler's ADRs climb roughly $3 on the week to $84.80, a 52-week high. "The bid shows that there is healthy interest in this asset," says David Herro, portfolio manager of the Oakmark International Fund. Herro's fund started buying shares at the end of '05 when he decided the poorly-managed, large industrial company had room for improvement. Herro, who buys the shares in Germany, continues to feel they have upside. At today's dollar/Euro exchange rate, Herro estimates the ADRs are worth closer to 115.   Chrysler wasn't the only acquisition target. First Data (FDC) agreed to be purchased by buyout shop Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for about $27 billion, making it potentially the second-largest deal ever attempted. The $34-a-share offer helped the stock jump 20% to $32.29. There was also news that investor Sam Zell would buy Tribune (TRB), and that Leon Black's Apollo Management was considering selling a 10% stake in itself to private investors.   Expect LBOs to remain in the headlines. "The basic alchemy of these deals is clear. If borrowing is cheap relative to the cash flows of companies, then there is a huge incentive to lever up and take the tax deduction for the interest paid," wrote Greg Jensen, co-chief investment officer of Bridgewater Associates in a recent report.   Jensen estimates that private-equity funds are sitting on more than $300 billion of undeployed capital. If you add on the typical leverage used to fund deals, it implies they have the ability to do acquisitions worth about $1 trillion.   So far, only scant signs of resistance have surfaced. Last week Realogy (H) had to offer stricter covenants and yields north of 10% on the junk bonds funding its $6.6 billion leveraged buyout by Apollo. Given the company's exposure to the residential real-estate industry, such added incentives shouldn't be a huge surprise.   Of more import may be the slim margin by which investors approved the $3.3 billion buyout of Four Seasons Hotels (FS). Investors participating in the buyout include founder Isadore Sharp, Bill Gates and Saudi Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal.   Nearly 70% of shareholder votes were cast in favor of the deal. Exclude the shares of those involved with the buyout, however, and shareholder approval fell to 52% -- just barely above the majority required for the deal to go through. Marsico Capital, which owns a 19% stake in the Four Seasons, previously objected  to the $82-a-share offer, even though it is  well above the  $63.87 the shares commanded before the bid emerged. Tom Marsico, head of the firm, could not be reached Friday.   This is the first sign that  investors could begin to make  things tougher for the barbarians at the gate.   The stock market certainly was helped by the 2.4% decline in crude oil prices to $64.28 last week, follwing Iran's release of 15 British sailors and marines. More surprising were the gains enjoyed by oil-related companies, despite the easing of geopolitical tensions and the commodity's decline. Exxon Mobil (XOM) jumped 1.77 on the week, to 77.22; Chevron (CVX) added 1.65, to 75.61 and Schlumberger tacked on 2.84, to 71.84.   Bruce Lanni, a senior oil analyst at A.G. Edwards, remains bullish on both oil prices and selected oil giants. With demand for oil expected to grow 1.7% this year and with 3% spare capacity, oil prices should remain in a range of $55 to $75, with a $61 average, he says. He figures it would take much higher prices than that to change consumption patterns.   The upshot: Lanni has buy recommendations on Exxon and Chevron, with target prices of 80 and 82, respectively. He's also optimistic about BP (BP) and Occidental Petroleum (OXY), which have price targets of 72 and 55.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Follow-Up: Promise And Danger In Magna Bid
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Chrysler helped bail out auto-parts supplier Magna International in the 1990 recession. Now, Magna might return the favor.   Frank Stronach, chairman of Ontario-based Magna (ticker: MGA), about which we've written several times over the years, wants to bid for Chrysler, which accounts for about 25% of Magna's $24 billion yearly sales and may be sold by its parent, DaimlerChrysler (DCX). To make a bid, Magna reportedly would team with private-equity firm Ripplewood Holdings, which includes Chrys-ler's ex-president, Thomas Stallkamp. Their proposal is said to be for $4.6 billion to $4.7 billion, with Magna taking a 20%-25% stake. Magna, with an $8.5 billion market value but a lot of cash, is too small to go it alone.   The rival bidders include Kirk Kerkorian, whose Tracinda Corp. last week announced an all-cash $4.5 billion offer.   Magna's strengths are its long history with Chrysler and the UAW's belief that Magna would keep it intact. Magna also can engineer and build entire vehicles -- its Magna Steyr unit produces the Chrysler PT Cruiser and BMW X3, among others, in Europe -- and it's long argued that auto companies one day will focus on design and sales, while outsourcing production. One big danger: a stake in Chrysler could hurt its relations with other auto makers.   Another problem: Both the Tracinda and Magna bids appear to be low-ball; DaimlerChrysler's hoping for $8 billion.   Regardless of what happens, Magna  -- now around 77, versus a 52-week high of 83.35 -- will stay under pressure until it improves margins in its interiors unit, which has been a drag on results.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Italy's Prodi Worried About Telecom Italia Breakup - Paper
Story: MILAN (Dow Jones)--Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi said he is worried Telecom Italia SpA (TIT.MI) could be split up into parts if it were acquired by AT&T Inc. (T) and America Movil S.A. (AMOV), he said in a newspaper interview published Saturday.   The announcement on April 1 by Telecom Italia's main shareholder, Pirelli & Co. SpA (PC.MI), that it's in exclusive talks with AT&T and America Movil, a Mexican cellular phone operator, to sell its stake in Italy's largest phone company drew immediate criticism from Italy's telecommunications minister.   Prodi, however, had kept silent until the interview  with Il Sole-24 Ore.   In the interview, Prodi didn't provide details about why he was concerned about a possible breakup, saying only he  suspects the talks are being driven by America Movil's desire to gain control of Telecom Italia's Brazilian cellular phone unit, Tim Brasil.   The government is following the talks intently, Prodi said, adding it's not directly involved.   "We are neither absent, nor reticent, nor intervening," Prodi said, adding that the market is the government's only "compass."   Prodi is known to be unhappy about the prospect of the company falling into foreign hands. One of his top advisors, Angelo Rovati, had to step down late last year when it emerged he had proposed a plan to Pirelli in which Telecom Italia's fixed line network would be spun off and then controlled by a government holding company.   Asked for his views on whether Mediaset SpA (MS.MI), the television broadcaster controlled by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, could be a potential buyer, Prodi said he thought that it wouldn't be feasible due to antitrust problems.   Prodi complained there were no Italian buyers for Pirelli's stake in Telecom Italia, which it holds through an unlisted company, Olimpia, which has 18% of Telecom Italia. He also said he didn't think other European governments would allow a foreign company to control one of their telecom giants.      Newspaper Web site: http://www.ilsole24ore.com     -By Jennifer Clark, Dow Jones Newswires; 39 335 833 5761; jennifer.clark@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 10:42 ET (14:42 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Televisa Network's Acapulco Correspondent Shot To Death
Story: ACAPULCO, Mexico (AP)--The Acapulco correspondent for Mexico's top television news network was shot to death after his radio show, the latest in a wave of journalist killings that have made Mexico the most dangerous country for reporters in the Western Hemisphere.   Televisa's Amado Ramirez was shot late Friday by two gunmen who were waiting for him at his car, state security official Felipe Flores said. Ramirez died on the steps of the nearby Hotel California as he tried to escape. Televisa confirmed the death on their nightly broadcast.   The shooting happened on the outskirts of Acapulco's busy central plaza, which was packed at the time with tourists and hundreds of people attending a Good Friday Mass at the beach resort's cathedral. No one else was injured.   The gunmen escaped, and the motive for the killing was not immediately clear.   Ramirez had covered Acapulco for Televisa for more than a dozen years, reporting on everything from crime to hurricanes.   Televisa official Luis Raul Gonzalez condemned the fatal shooting on the network's nightly broadcast, and he called on police to find the killers. The network also aired the last report Ramirez did before he was killed. The tourism segment showed the reporter interviewing tourists who packed Acapulco's beaches for Easter vacation.   Ramirez's radio program on Friday focused on criticizing leftist Guerrero state Gov. Zeferino Torreblanca for refusing to give his second state-of-the-state address in front of state lawmakers. The governor instead chose to give his report in written form.   The Miami-based Inter-American Press Association has reported an alarming number of journalists slain in Mexico on orders from drug gangs, with seven journalists killed since October, two disappeared and eight reporting death threats.   "I would say Mexico has become the country (in the Western Hemisphere) where it's most dangerous to be a journalist today," Gonzalo Marroquin, president of the IAPA's press freedom commission, said last month.   Since taking office Dec. 1, conservative Mexican President Felipe Calderon has sent federal police and soldiers into drug strongholds across Mexico, including Acapulco, but violence continues.   Also Friday evening in Acapulco, a shootout between police and alleged kidnappers left one suspect dead and another wounded, Flores said. A businessman believed to have been held by the kidnappers was released unharmed.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 06:54 ET (10:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: Fixing Fidelity
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   There are four essential ways in which stock-fund managers can try to beat the market and outrun the competition. They can be bigger, faster, smarter or more patient.   For years, Fidelity Investments was the biggest in the business. It remains a giant, but the advantages of size have been eroded by regulation and technology. And a firm of Fidelity's heft and broad customer base never could compete on speed in a market where computer programs fling stocks around infive-millisecond increments.   So, as the big Boston investment company retools its stock-picking process in a bid to reverse several years of middling returns and sluggish cash inflows, it is focusing -- by necessity -- on smarts and patience.   Fidelity is about midway through a four- or five-year campaign to make its equity-investment division smarter and sharper. The effort involves adding breadth and depth to its in-house stock-research department, altering its long-held hiring-and-promotion practices, consolidating the equity-investing staff to foster better communication and recasting its relationship with Wall Street brokers.   Vice Chairman and Chief Operating Officer Robert Reynolds, who assumed direct oversight of Fidelity's money-management division in January, says that in 2005, "We made a decision to change the fundamental way Fidelity sets up research."   Reynolds took responsibility for the investment-management group and the ongoing restructuring when Stephen Jonas left the firm early this year to take a break from the business. Reynolds, in a recent interview at Fidelity's Boston headquarters, acknowledged that the research turnaround is a work in progress.   "We're now at halftime of the game," he says.   Last year, 44% of the firm's actively managed diversified equity funds ranked in the top half of their categories, according to Morningstar. Fidelity also ranked 38th among the 67 fund complexes in the 2006 Barron's/Lipper fund-family rankings published two months ago.   Over three, five and 10 years, the proportion of Fidelity stock funds outperforming the average peer was 55%, 56% and 52%, respectively, says Morningstar.   In other words, results have been decidedly mediocre.   Fidelity's long stay in the middle of the pack has cooled investors' ardor for its offerings and allowed rivals to overtake Fidelity in total assets. Net new assets in Fidelity's long-term funds (excluding the money-market funds that scoop up billions through its huge discount brokerage) totaled $15.2 billion in the 12 months ended Feb. 28, reports Financial Research, a firm that tracks such things. That compares with $76.7 billion for Capital Research's American Funds and $52.1 billion for index-fund specialist Vanguard.   It should be noted that Fidelity's inflows could have been crimped by the company's conscientious decision to close several large and popular funds to new investors last year, including Growth Company, Mid-Cap Stock and Contrafund -- Fidelity's largest, at $68.7 billion.   The initiative to rethink research at Fidelity was rooted in developments that go back at least five years. Fidelity's vast size, prodigious trading activity and outsized ownership position in so many stocks once gave it the inside track in getting information from corporate executives, sell-side analysts and brokerage trading desks.   CEOs would cultivate Fidelity above all other investors. Analysts would give its portfolio managers the vaunted "first call." And its heavy trading meant that its traders picked up Street scuttlebutt faster than other players.   Then came Regulation FD, mandating that companies disclose material information to all investors at once, and the Wall Street analyst-conflict scandals. The brokerage-house research settlement with regulators upended the Wall Street business model of linking research with banking, and drove sell-side firms to slash their research budgets and shrink their stock-coverage universe.   Fidelity recognized -- arguably, a bit late -- that a deeper in-house research operation was a necessity as the Street's service level declined. In the Regulation FD world, too, more feet on the pavement and ears to the ground meant that the company could glean more analytical nuggets as companies held information close to the vest.   As a result, in less than two years, Fidelity has doubled the size of its domestic stock-research corps, based in Boston, to 180 analysts, and has changed how they're hired and cultivated.   Through the decades, Fidelity hired new college and business-school graduates as analysts almost exclusively and then groomed them in its system. Each was assigned to cover an industry and perhaps allowed to run one of the Fidelity Select sector funds, for a brief period, before being cycled through to another sector. The aim was to create generalists, steeped in the cult of the heroic analytical-cum-instinctive stock picker, as embodied by the great Peter Lynch and others.   Recognizing that this created a broad smattering of sector exposure at the expense of deep industry knowledge, management created "multiple career paths," notes equity-investing chief Walter Donovan. Now, if an analyst enjoys and excels in covering a single industry, he or she can keep watch on it indefinitely.   Donovan relates an anecdote about an analyst fresh out of school who was given responsibility for covering steel companies a couple of years ago and delved into the industry. "We forgot to tell him that steel was a lousy business," he recalls. So the analyst crafted a bullish thesis and got multiple Fidelity funds into the group in 2005, in time to catch its powerful, multiyear upside push.   Rather than funneling everyone toward a portfolio-management role, Fidelity now holds open the option of remaining a career analyst, generating stock ideas for multiple fund managers. This approach long has been followed by the likes of Capital Research, AllianceBernstein and State Street Research & Management (now part of BlackRock).   The firm has also begun recruiting experienced hands, rather than kids fresh off the campus, to import more tangible expertise and improve the quality of the intellectual ferment that fuels investment decisions. Once Fidelity made it known that it would consider bringing seasoned analysts aboard, "We got hundreds of applications," Reynolds says. Among the new recruits: a 24-year sell-side veteran who covers energy, another sell-sider with 11 years' experience following pharmaceuticals, a third with 11 years on the job focusing on software and IT services, and a 12-year analyst from a rival buy-side shop specializing in media and Internet stocks.   To foster productive cross-pollination of ideas and inter-sector insights, Fidelity has collected its various investment teams and trading desks -- formerly strewn across multiple buildings -- on two floors of a single building, with large trading floors in the middle.   In addition, Fidelity has created a layer of stock coverage "on top of industry research," a large-cap research group focused on the largest 200 global companies. It also hived off its large institutional asset-management operations into a separate unit, honing a focus on the public mutual funds.   Donovan says that these moves are aimed at achieving "more coverage, with more communication. We think that's the way to win for the next five, 10, 15 years," though he stresses that Fidelity's approach is "still fundamental stock-picking, still a meritocracy."   It's a bit too early to find tangible fund-by-fund performance results from these new practices. In the past year, certainly, the story was mixed at best for the firm's largest offerings.   Contrafund, run by Will Danoff since 1990, trailed the S&P 500's 15.8% return last year by a stinging four percentage points. But it was in the top 15% of all large-cap growth funds and over the past three years is in elite company, in the top 2%. Joel Tillinghast's Low-Priced Stock fund continues to hold its own, with a top-quartile ranking over the past three years.   Of course, for years Fidelity's most glaring disappointment has been Magellan, the fund at which Lynch built his legend. Below-average performance and a slow bleed of investor withdrawals have shrunk Magellan's assets to $43 billion, from a 2000 peak of $105 billion. After up-and-down results in the decade under Robert Stansky -- mostly down toward the end --  Magellan was handed to veteran Fidelity manager Harry Lange on Oct. 31, 2005.   Lange immediately overhauled the portfolio, which had been rather index-like with a focus on stable mega-cap names. Robin Carpenter, who runs the consulting firm Carpenter Analytics, notes that Lange's arrival immediately made the fund's performance more variable, indicating larger bets being made away from the benchmark.   To date, the makeover hasn't produced any big benefits. Magellan lagged behind the S&P 500 in 2006 by a yawning 8.6 percentage points, though it trailed the laggard Russell 1000 Growth benchmark by far less: 1.87%. But this year, Magellan is off to a strong start, returning 4.2% through Wednesday, more than double the S&P 500's gain.   Lange has truly built the fund, by design or not, for a ripping global bull market, with 28% in tech stocks and more than a quarter of all assets in non-U.S. names. As of Dec. 31, four of the five largest holding were tech-related -- Nokia (ticker:NOK), Corning (GLW), Google (GOOG) and Seagate Technology (STX).   Anyone who wants to bet on the long-predicted but so-far absent return of large growth stocks to the fore after seven years of value-stock dominance could find Magellan a good vehicle, if it weren't closed to new investors. Yet if the market is choppy and commodity-related stocks and utilities stay at its forefront, the fund's holders could be quite unhappy.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:10 ET (04:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Plugged In: A Bet For An Era Of Excess
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tiernan Ray   It doesn't take a savant to see that the telecommunications business is in a period of wild excess.   For example, Savvis, an "alternative" telecom deep in the red, will quintuple its spending this year over last year's level, in order to host Websites -- for a fee -- for marquee clients such as Reuters.   Excess sometimes can be mistaken for success. (In 2005, Savvis' then-CEO made a splash in the tabloids for allegedly spending more than $200,000 at a Manhattan strip club.) Sell-side analysts speculate that large telcos might acquire fast-growing outfits like Savvis at a hefty premium. This has helped Savvis shares (ticker: SVVS) more than double in the past 12 months; they recently were around 48.   But if you're not one to bet on buyouts, it makes sense to look for alternative high-growth telecoms that are profitable. One is Atlanta-based Cbeyond (CBEY), which has an $800 million stock-market value. Its shares have risen by more than 90% in the past 12 months, to around 30.50, but the stock is still cheaper than Savvis', based on earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (Ebitda, a measure of cash flow). And the company expects heady sales growth of 30% this year. A valuation closer to Savvis' would suggest 16% upside to Cbeyond's stock.   Like Savvis, Cbeyond is growing fast. It sells phone lines to companies with 250 or fewer employees, but it runs the calls as packets of Internet-protocol data. In this way, it can merge several services into a single product, benefitting clients. It can, for example, make a call ring on either an employee's desk phone or Blackberry -- using one phone number, no matter where the person is.   Unlike conventional phone companies, which dig up the street to lay fiber and copper lines, Cbeyond and other alternative telecoms just buy computers and lease bandwidth as they need it -- making it cheap to add customers.   Cbeyond's CEO, Jim Geiger, seems to have figured out these economics better than his peers. By leasing new bandwidth in cities only as the company adds customers, Geiger has held capital outlays to about 20% of sales per year. The company rang up $214 million in sales last year from 27,343 customers, and earned $8 million, or 27 cents a share, while adding cash -- it has $44 million -- and avoiding debt.   In contrast, firms such as Savvis are spending like crazy to have the biggest facilities to capture the biggest chunk of businesses like Web hosting, which are growing at 20% or more a year. Savvis will likely spend roughly $350 million this year -- about 40% of its projected total sales -- to build new facilities, writes Cowen and Co. research analyst Tom Watts. The company has about $384 million in debt, but its stock trades at a premium to Cbeyond's. Savvis' enterprise value (stock-market value, minus net debt) is 19.4 times its expected 2007 Ebitda, versus about 17 for Cbeyond.   The speculative mindset says that companies such as Savvis are worth a premium, even as they lose more money. They're capturing Internet-oriented business that Verizon and AT&T aren't. Plus, the more they lose, the more tax-loss carryforwards they build up, and these could be attractive to an acquirer seeking to defray taxes. But Cbeyond is capturing more buisness, too, and there are indications that its margins are expanding. In any case, it offers a more conservative bet that could pay off nicely, even in an era of excess.   ---   A version of this column appeared April 4 on Barron's Online.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Publicis Groupe: SEC Filing Annual Report on Form 20-F
Story: PARIS, April 7 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Publicis Groupe S.A. (NYSE: PUB) announced today that it has filed its Annual Report on Form 20-F, for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2006, with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC"). A copy of this annual report on Form 20-F, which also includes the Company's complete audited financial statements, is available to download on its website at www.publicisgroupe.com or http://www.publicisgroupe.com/site/media/2006_20-F.pdf. Copies of the annual report on Form 20-F, including copies of the Company's audited financial statements included in the report, are available, free of charge, to all shareholders and can be ordered online at investor-relations@publicis.com or by calling Investor Relations at +33(0)1-44-43-65-00.     Publicis Groupe (Euronext Paris: FR0000130577 and NYSE: PUB) is the world's fourth largest communications group, as well as world's second largest media counsel and buying group. With activities spanning 104 countries on five continents, the Groupe employs approximately 40,000 professionals.     The Groupe's communication activities cover advertising, through three autonomous global advertising networks: Leo Burnett, Publicis, Saatchi & Saatchi, as well as through its two multi-hub networks Fallon Worldwide and 49%-owned Bartle Bogle Hegarty; media consultancy and buying through two worldwide networks ZenithOptimedia and Starcom MediaVest Group; interactive and digital marketing, marketing services and specialized communications including direct marketing, public relations, corporate and financial communications, event communications, multicultural and healthcare communications.        Web sites: www.publicisgroupe.com and www.finance.publicisgroupe.com    SOURCE  Publicis Groupe       /CONTACT: Contact Publicis Groupe: Eve Magnant, Corporate Communications Director: +33(0)1-44-43-70-25     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 07:32 ET (11:32 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(4/9) A Wall-To-Wall Wonder
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Sherrie Gibson needed to look only as far as the dressing-room floors of The Black Parrot, her Rockland, Maine, clothing and home-furnishings store, to find the best floor covering for her heavily trafficked entryways. Her choice: FLOR, an easy-to-install line of carpet-tile made by Interface -- because it was a more versatile option than the broadloom wall-to-wall carpet she had been considering.   With more and more businesses going for the tile style, these are goodtimes for Atlanta-based Interface, the world's leading commercial carpet-tile maker. The carpeting, made up of a series of discrete tile-shaped pieces, is not only cheaper to lay, but far easier to maintain than conventional carpeting; you can remove any tile and clean it, or swap in a new one. And, thanks in no small part to Interface, the carpeting is available in increasingly stylish patterns, many of which allow for easy replacement.   Those advantages have sparked what CEO Dan Hendrix calls a "modular explosion." Sales of carpet tile have grown four times faster than those of other types of carpet ordered by architects and designers since 2001, says Wachovia Capital Markets. And the sales aren't just to offices: Retailers, education facilities and medical centers increasingly are choosing carpet-tile.   Interface has the market covered like a rug. Roughly 70% of its $1 billion-plus in annual sales comes from modular carpeting. It has grabbed a full one-third of the $1.1 billion U.S. industry, and looks to be doing brisk business overseas.   Interface shares, for their part, have climbed from a low of $2 a share at the depths of the 2002 economic downturn to $16.30, as the company has diversified its customer base, reduced debt and shed non-core businesses.   There's every reason to think the good times will continue. Fans think the company will see its revenue advance by about 10% in the next year and at a compound 25% over the next three years, thanks to the growing demand for carpet-tile. That's not just from offices -- hotels, schools, and medical centers are taking to the floor covering, too.   CEO Hendrix says the commercial market "remains very robust," and that the cycle for office furnishings is in the early stages of what is typically a seven- or eight-year period of growth following a downturn. He notes, too, that the market for carpet-tile is experiencing a secular shift, and he expects capet-tile's share of total carpeting ordered by designers to double, to two-thirds, over the next 10 years.   Another big plus: Hendrix continues to slash debt. The company's debt-to-capital ratio fell to 52% from 73% last year. Net debt slid to $300 million from $500 million just two years ago. While Hendrix says he's "comfortable" with the current level, his goal is to get net debt closer to $200 million.   Some investors expect Interface to sell its underperforming commercial-fabric business, which includes the Guilford of Maine and Terratex brands, as well as its lagging Bentley Prince Street line of high-end commercial broadloom carpet and tiles, perhaps as soon as this year, and then use the proceeds to cut debt further.   "We don't comment on acquisitions or disposals of businesses," says Hendrix, but he points out that a decision was made in 2002 to focus on Interface's  carpet-tile business, "and that will continue" because it is the fastest-growing part of the company.   Interface certainly benefits from its longstanding reputation as an eco-friendly manufacturer. Inspired after reading the environmental classic, The Ecology of Commerce: A Declaration of Sustainability, by fellow entrepreneur Paul Hawken 13 years ago, Interface founder and chairman Ray Anderson committed the company to being green. That's become an important competitive advantage. Interface routinely ranks among the top in surveys on sustainable development and corporate responsibility because of its attention to reducing waste and emissions in manufacturing. It even encourages the return of worn carpet tiles for recycling.   Although focused on business clients, Interface doesn't ignore homeowners. Long a staple in higher-end contemporary-design shops, such as Design Within Reach and Crate and Barrel's CB2, Interface is making a bigger push into the mass residential market. For the past two years, its wares have been available at Lowe's home-improvement stores. Interface is expanding this year into Target with its affordable $59.99 "Rug in a Box" mix-and-match set of FLOR tiles, and a Martha Stewart-branded line is expected to be launched this year. Catalogs promoting FLOR tiles are ending up in mailboxes around the country. Hendrix sees the retail segment turning profitable later this year.   It all adds up to a promising stock. Barron's took a shine to the shares (ticker: IFSIA) last fall when they were around $13 (The Trader, Sept. 18, 2006). At 16.30 now, there's still ample upside. Price targets range from 20 to 22, levels not seen in nine years. That would be a  gain of 25% to 37.5%.   Trading at 16-to-18 times estimated earnings of 90 cents to $1 this year, and just over 12 times one bull's aggressive projection of $1.25 to $1.30 a share next year, the stock appears reasonably valued, given the pace of profit growth.   Chad Kilmer of William Blair's Value Discovery Fund, argues that 15%-20% annual gains in earnings are sustainable. He first bought Interface shares a year ago and continues to see opportunity as a result of the "terrific" fundamentals and the shift to carpet-tile from other types of floor coverings.   Yes, there are competitors: Publicly-held Mohawk Industries (MHK) and the privately held Shaw Industries, which is owned by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRK/A), have long been in the carpet-tile business. But they are more heavily exposed to the traditional, broadloom carpet and residential market.   Kilmer considers Interface more akin to high-end commercial office-furnishing companies, such as Herman Miller (MLHR) and Knoll (KNL), and commercial-lighting outfits Acuity Brands (AYI), Genlyte (GLYT) and Hubbell (HUB). Compared with that group, Interface is growing faster and trading more cheaply: Its enterprise value is eight times estimated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization for 2007, versus nine times for the group. Its estimated 41% earnings growth for 2007 towers above the group's 23%.   The big risk to the shares is a sharp and prolonged slowdown in the U.S. economy. But Kilmer says that Interface should do just fine if the economy grows at a moderate 2% to 2.5% and the office-vacancy rate keeps declining. About 70% of its office business is related to refurbishment, not new construction. And the company is seeing positive trends in Europe. CEO Hendrix notes that the European office market, outside of London, is rebounding after 10 years in the doldrums, with Eastern Europe showing particular strength.   If that's the case, this carpet-maker's stock has more than a solid floor: It has a high ceiling, too.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Carriers Mull Suing Airbus For Overweight Aircraft - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Airlines are considering suing Airbus after the aircraft manufacturer warned them that the front-end of the A340-900 was dangerously overweight, The Times reported Saturday citing aviation sources.   The first- and business-class sections on some A340-600s are so heavy that they are pushing the jet's nose down during flight, which can impact aerodynamics and potentially endanger passengers and crew, the newspaper said.   A number of airlines are insisting that it is Airbus's error and are considering suing for lost cargo income, according to The Times.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 44 (0)20 7842-9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 05:24 ET (09:24 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Allianz Sheds Its Accident-Prone Past
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By George Frey   When Michael Diekmann assumed the chief excutive job at German insurer Allianz four years ago this month, the global financial giant had just reported a record quarterly loss after a costly acquisition of Dresdner Bank and had posted big provisions for Sept. 11 and asbestos claims in the U.S. Investors had watched their shares go into free fall, losing about 80% of their value. At last, the insurer, with Diekmann at the helm, seems to have put that nasty string of disasters behind it.   Best known in the U.S. for its Pimco money-management and Fireman's Fund insurance businesses, Allianz is beginning to see the results of a restructuring that emphasizes efficiency and simplicity in its global operations. Coupled with fewer natural disasters and rising capital markets, the program produced vastly improved profits in 2006 and has allowed the insurance, banking and asset-management company to lift earnings projections through 2009 and propose a series of dividend hikes.   "We're not only on the right track, but are also keeping up the pace," Diekmann told a recent press conference. "With a tailwind of strong 2006 results at our back, a raft of specific challenges for the current fiscal year ahead of us, and a clear course for the future, we are well-positioned to deliver the sustainable improvements needed," said the 52-year old chief executive.   Long-term investors are starting to get some of their money back. Although nowhere near their 2000 peak around 400 euros ($532 at today's rates), the German DAX-traded shares (ticker: ALV.Germany) have left their 2003 low under 50 euros far behind and are up 14% in the past year, to 157.85 euros. Some analysts believe the shares still have room to rise 20% or more over the next 12 months. Allianz's American depositary shares (AZ) have trekked a similar course in recent years, and were quoted at $21.31 last week.   The shares still look relatively cheap. Paul Goodhind, an analyst with Bear Stearns in London, said in a recent note: "The valuation case for Allianz remains compelling, with the shares trading on a modest nine times 2008 earnings. While the shares may pause in the near term, evidence that Allianz is on track to achieve its targets should lead to further outperformance." Allianz's French rival AXA carries a price-earnings ratio near 15, the insurance industry's general benchmark. Goodhind has a year-end price target of 195 euros, or about 25% above the recent levels.   Under Diekmann, the 118-year-old Munich-based institution has pursued a broad set of goals it calls "3+One," which aim to improve its capital base, raise profits, and streamline a corporate structure that was complex even by Germany's labyrinthine standards. The final (+One) objective is increasing competitiveness and long-term value.   Allianz, which still makes the vast majority of its money from insurance, is clearly starting to hit some of its new benchmarks. For 2006, Allianz booked a 60% gain in net profit to 7 billion euros (about $9.3 billion), from the 4.4 billion euros net in 2005. Operating profit hit 10.4 billion euros -- up almost 30% over 2005. Total revenues rose just 0.2% to 101 billion euros, owing to weaker fourth-quarter insurance sales in Italy and the U.S.   At the time of the earnings release, Allianz said it had raised its expectations for operating profit growth to about 10% annually until '09, and proposed to lift its '06 dividend by 90% to 3.80 euros, suggesting further that it would continue raising its payout for at least the next two years.   In substance, the 3+One program has meant reductions in management layers, centralization of operations and systems in areas like information technology and the consolidation of its minority stakes in various insurance businesses. It's also put more emphasis on selling in fast-growing emerging markets like China and India, where demand for insurance and other financial services is booming, and is pushing the insurance and banking units to cross-sell products more aggressively.   To gain greater control, realize more efficiencies and enable faster response to cross-border opportunities, Allianz earlier this year merged Italian unit RAS Holding more fully into its fold and is in the process of buying out the 9% minority stake of its German life-insurance company Allianz Lebensversicherung. In March, Allianz launched a bid for the 42.2% of the equity it doesn't own in Assurances Generales de France. These moves, note the parent company, "will help us to further increase operational efficiency and enhance efficient capital usage." Together, the deals are worth about 16.5 billion euros.   Allianz, which oversees Europe's biggest insurer by premium income, also recently changed its corporate legal status to a Societas Europaea (SE) from an Aktiengesellschaft (AG), a historic switch from a German to a pan-European entity that should facilitate its cross-border business.   Across the Atlantic, the company has consolidated administration of Allianz of America Holding to bring IT, human resources and legal services into a joint back office. "We are reaping significant cost benefits and improving the efficiency of our work," Diekmann says of these changes. "This will enable the subsidiaries Fireman's Fund and AZ Life to concentrate better on the development and sale of customer-oriented products."   All of these initiatives show promise, says Konrad Becker, an analyst at Merck Finck & Co. in Munich. Buyouts and consolidations should make overall business more efficient, and give Allianz a bigger market -- putting it on a more competitive footing with industry peers by improving its distribution channels, Becker says.   Emerging markets have become a key area of growth that will become even more important as local regulatory barriers fall. Allianz is focused on Brazil, Russia, India and China, and has said emerging Europe looks promising, too.   In all, emerging markets generated more than 10 billion euros in 2006 gross premiums, while Allianz' total gross premiums were basically flat at just over 91 billion euros. The company says although "revenues from these countries were still small just three years ago, the situation has since changed radically," especially as a middle class starts building; in India alone, Allianz is adding about 400,000 customers a month for insurance and financial products.   Even Dresdner Bank -- whose ill-fated foray into investment banking along with other problems contributed heavily to Allianz's big losses in 2002 -- is in improved health. In 2006, Allianz's banking operations, which consist mainly of Dresdner, had revenues of 7.1 billion euros, versus 6.3 billion euros a year earlier. Operating profit rose to 1.4 billion euros, compared with just 704 million euros in 2005, but its 918 million euros in net profit weakened on restructuring charges.   While the 24 billion euros acquisition of Dresdner in 2001 is still controversial, the division has stabilized and will be a key participant in Allianz's cross-selling strategy, which will be a major determinant of the insurer's growth in Germany.   Allianz says only 22% of its 20 million-plus insurance customers in Germany have policies in more than one line of insurance business; just 4% have policies in all -- property, casualty, life and health. Meanwhile, only 10% of insurance customers have Dresdner Bank accounts and less than half the bank customers have Allianz insurance.   Allianz is starting to offer both banking and insurance products at some of its retail-bank and insurance outlets. That's near-heretical in tradition-bound Germany, where those businesses usually sell only their own branded ingredients. About 5% of Dresdner's 900 German branches now sell property and casualty insurance, and 12% sell life and health insurance. Parent Allianz is intent on improving those percentages.   Allianz Global Investors -- which includes Pimco, RCM Capital Management, NJF Investment, Nicholas-Applegate and Oppenheimer Capital -- remains a steady contributor. The group had revenues of 3 billion euros last year, up from 2.7 billion euros in 2005. Operating profit rose to 1.3 billion euros, compared with 1.1 billion eurow in the prior year.   As encouraging as all its recent progress is, Allianz has lots of room to improve its performance and reward shareholders further. Says Bear Stearns' Goodhind: "A question remains about what they'll do with their excess capital. Allianz doesn't need to hold all that cash."   As retained earnings grow, excess capital will probably accumulate at a rate of around 3 billion euros a year before long, according to Goodhind's projections. While Allianz is striving to get closer to its peers' standard of 30% to 40% dividend-payout rates by 2008, it could return more of that cash to shareholders through a share buyback, the analyst says. Goodhind reckons the company could afford to spend between 2 billion euros and 4 billion euros over the next two years for just that -- something Allianz hasn't ruled out.   Goodhind also said Allianz could divest the Dresdner Kleinwort investment-banking business, its credit-insurance business Euler Hermes and its international corporate and industrial-insurance carrier, Allianz Global Risks. He estimates that the disposals could generate about 10 billion euros in all. But Allianz has said it's not selling.   What's more, Dresdner' cost-income ratio is still too high, in Goodhind's view. "Or their revenues are too low, however you want to look at it," he says. He also puts Dresdner's return on capital at about 13%, well below the 20% that top bank performers achieve. The company has said that an average return on risk-adjusted capital of above 15% per year is its near-term goal.   In light of Diekmann's recent performance, you have to believe Allianz will get there soon.   ---   George Frey, a free-lance reporter, covers business from Frankfurt.   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: Quietly, Bangalore Connection Grows
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   Every day, Maltesh Somasekharappa talks about stocks or interest rates with his fellow analyst at a mutual fund in London. But Maltesh, as he's known, doesn't work directly for that fund. Instead, he does research for it from Bangalore, where he's employed by Wipro, one of India's most prominent blue-chip companies.   Maltesh, who has been working with the London fund for four months, is at the forefront of a development that few mutual-fund investors knowof. Increasingly, fund companies in Europe and the U.S. are outsourcing stock research to India, where it can be done more cheaply.   The bright 32-year-old grew up four hours outside Bangalore, where his parents still own an auto-parts maker and a rice farm. His international resume is impressive. After graduating from the London School of Economics in 2001, he worked in the British capital as a European small-cap analyst for Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, now part of Germany's Allianz.   Midway through 2003, he happened to look at a chart comparing the ascent of Indian shares with those of European and U.S. stocks. It was a startling revelation. "I realized that England was growing 2.5% a year; India, 8.5%. If I wanted to grow faster, I needed to be in the tide that flows faster."   So Maltesh -- whose sister is a software engineer in Illinois -- moved back to his homeland to start a firm that did research for corporate-finance teams in the U.K. Later, he worked for Infosys Technologies, India's top information-technology outsourcer. There, he met his future boss, Ramit Sethi. Last fall, the two joined NYSE-listed Wipro (ticker: WIT), which does, among other things, investment research for a growing roster of U.S. financial outfits.   For some years, fund companies have outsourced back-office operations and some aspects of marketing. Now they're taking a page from Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan and from hedge funds, dipping a toe into off-shoring investment research. The funds are being very low-key about this; Maltesh would speak to Barron's only on condition that we didn't identify the London fund he deals with.   Fidelity Investments has 4,700 people in India doing back-office work and the like. Fidelity is generally tightlipped about the operation but does say it has 20 analysts there, focused on quantitative, credit and equity research -- a handful compared with its 300 analysts in the U.S. But people in India familiar with the operation say the fund giant has been hiring heavily.   Franklin Templeton has its global library in Mumbai, which provides research for the U.S. team and risk-management analysis. Capital Research readily admits it outsources about 5% of its research, although it does so to Wall Street firms. Other big firms are beginning to follow suit but either wouldn't comment or denied it outright.   Soon, the analyst you hear on the corporate conference call grilling management about quarterly earnings could be in Chennai or Bangalore rather than Chicago or Boston. Says Mark Halverson, the senior executive handling investment-management services for Accenture: "I'm not sure I know any active manager with at least $150 billion in assets that isn't looking at it."   Comments Girish Paranjpe, chief of Wipro's banking and financial-services operation: "There's a large pool of people with mathematical [skills] and the ability to express themselves in India -- and the cost advantage goes without saying. I'd say it's about five times."   Thus far, any savings haven't been translated into lower costs for fund investors. On average, equity funds still charge 1.46% of assets each year to manage your money. "I would think that an investor would do best buying shares of the companies that are outsourcing their research rather than buying the company's funds," says Daniel P. Wiener, CEO of Adviser Investment Management, a Newton, Mass., money manager.   Ultimately, however, to justify the outsourcing, funds will have to pass some of the savings to investors.   Historically, asset managers bought research from investment banks. Then came the 2003 settlement between securities firms and New York's then-attorney general, Elliot Spitzer, after a scandal over allegedly tainted research and conflicts of interest. Fidelity moved to spend $100 million to beef up research, and other buy-side firms followed suit. Meanwhile, India's outsourcing industry was spreading from information technology to other areas, including investment research. Among the providers: Adventity, Copal Partners and Irevna (part of a Standard & Poor's unit).   According to the Tabb Group, which tracks research outlays, buy-side firms in the U.K. and the U.S. spent more than $15 billion on research last year. From 2000 through 2006, Tabb reckons, the number of sell-side equity analysts fell in the U.K. and U.S. by more than 40%, to 9,300. And even as the number of Americans taking the chartered-financial-analyst exam fell by 25% in that period, the number taking it in India rose fivefold.   Over all, banks and funds could be spending $20 billion by 2011 on outsourced financial analytics, estimates Niket Patankar, Adventity's chief executive. For mutual funds, that number could be about $5 billion (versus "tens of millions of dollars" today). Adventity has 2,200 employees now, and just got $20 million in funding from a venture capitalist. Patankar hopes to bring his company public late next year.   Last October, rival ExlService (EXLS) went public on Nasdaq at $13.50 a share then ran up as high as 29.24. Recently, it traded around 20 -- or 35 times trailing earnings for the last four quarters.   Buy-side research is attractive to other outsourcers, including privately held Zenta Group, which has 1,500 people in Chennai, a hotbed for accounting, and does financial analysis for the real-estate industry. "It's a natural fit for us," says Zenta's senior vice president, David Jones. "If you can do cash-flow models, it's directly applicable."   The Indian analysts maintain financial models on large numbers of companies, updating them for earnings or shifts in interest rates, assessing regulatory changes' impact on cash flows, assessing whether mergers are accretive and examining many other factors.   Some junior analysts in India are paired with portfolio managers in the U.S. "About 90% of kicking tires is analyzing information and talking on the phone at your desk, analyzing data through the Internet or through paid-subscription databases," says Patankar.
