With corporate-earnings conference calls, "the Indian folks do get a chance to be on the call and get first-hand information."   Purveyors of research know that outsourcing is a touchy subject that often comes under close scrutiny from those whose jobs are threatened. Adventity, says Patankar, "has zero tolerance for errors. The work product that comes out of India is equivalent to Harvard MBAs'. They provide more granular research and more finely tuned analysis." Indeed, Patankar maintains, some firms already slap their brand names on Adventity research without changing a word.   For now, however, the Indian analysts stop short of making outright stock recommendations -- though that can't be far away. "Technically, you could offshore the whole thing in the next 10 years," says Patankar. That would raise another issue. "If this goes beyond simply plugging numbers into spreadsheets, then it calls into question the value of many fund firms' research operations," says fund manager Dan Wiener.   Adds Larry Lieberman, a mutual-fund-industry headhunter with Princeton, N.J.-based Orion Group: "It's just as easy to have a black box in Bangalore as it is to have it here. At the end of the day, if they can get the research done better and cheaper -- go for it. You have a fiduciary duty to provide the lowest possible prices to your customers."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Barron's Mailbag: Whipped Or Cream?
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     Regarding "A Latte Room to Grow," March 26: Analysis does not support a sudden improvement in Starbucks' fortunes. The stock sports a huge price/earnings ratio for a company whose growth is not accelerating, but falling. There's a serious increase in competition from McDonalds and Dunkin' Donuts. There's an increase in the price of coffee beans. Last but not least, there has been enormous insider selling.   The "Bottom Line"claim that as "same-store sales and profit margins improve, the stock could rally into the mid-40s" is a contradiction of the reality stated in the article. Same-store sales and margins are decreasing.   Dr. Gary Haber   Delray Beach, Fla.     To the Editor:     The recent Starbucks article suggests that Starbucks once grew earnings faster; such growth will return; and the shares will achieve their higher legacy multiple. However, the facts suggest otherwise: (1) even with recent stock-price softness, Starbucks shares' free cash flow yield is well below the 10-year Treasury yield; (2) gross profit growth is meaningfully slower than revenue growth due to lower-margin international growth and domestic food sales growth that is outpacing higher-margin beverage growth; unlike in prior years, Ebitda growth was meaningfully slower than revenue growth in every quarter of 2006.   For a growth stock to achieve and maintain a P/E higher than its revenue growth rate, the company must have positive operating leverage, not the negative operating leverage that Starbucks' last four quarters show. The current P/E-to-Growth ratio of 1.4 seems risky.   Jim Lane   TriPoint Asset Management   Boston   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: Sprouting A Hint Of Green
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   In retrospect, the first quarter's headlines were far more alarming than mutual funds' final tally. A global selloff on Feb. 27 handed U.S. stocks their worst one-day point drubbing since the Sept. 11 attacks, and February gave the market its first loss in nine months.   What followed were more volatile jags in March. Suddenly, a market that hadn't been too perturbed by anything now seems worried about everything: slowing economic growth, a long-anticipated ebb in corporate profits, tension with Iran and the trudge of crude oil towards $70.   Through it all, however, the 7,977 U.S. diversified equity funds tracked by Lipper posted an average return of 2.1%, outpacing the 0.2% first-quarter rise in the Standard & Poor's 500. (With dividends reinvested, the S&P  returned 0.64% in the quarter.) This was a far cry from the second half of last year, when money managers trailed and chased after the market's unflagging rally, and it's an indication that shrewd stock-picking is paying off in a more erratic market.   Bulls believe that the complacent and overbought stock market -- the Dow Jones Industrial Average had gone nearly 950 days without a one-day drop of more than 2% -- is now healthier after the shakeout. Nearly every fund type managed gains, no mean feat,  given the violence of the late-February mauling. But funds with a short bias, which outgunned their peers as recently as mid-March, saw their gains slip quickly into the red as stocks bounced back resoundingly and rapidly from the recent selloff.   Still, their decline pales in comparison with the only other group with a conspicuous loss. Financial-services funds fell 1.82%, as investors fretted about rising defaults in the mortgage market and possible contagion from the wobbly subprime sector, and how tightening credit might affect financial-sector profits.   Despite the steady chorus singing the virtues of big stocks -- all together, now: cheap valuations, more stable profits, global exposure -- large-cap funds' gains of less than 1% trailed the 3.2% racked up by small-cap growth funds and the 2.6% by small-cap value funds.   But it is perhaps a sign of the times that mid-caps outpaced them all. Mid-cap growth funds were up 4.3%; mid-cap value funds, 4.4%. For one thing, these companies have market values caught squarely in the cross-hairs of leveraged-buyout firms, and baked-in takeover premiums have kept stock prices elevated. "Talk is also rife that the outperformance of small stocks is nearing an end, yet performance of large-cap stocks hasn't been that compelling yet," says Lipper senior analyst Jeff Tjornehoj. "So investors gravitating up the capitalization ladder are splitting the difference and settling on the mid-caps."   The mid-cap Hennessy Focus 30 Fund (ticker: HFTFX), for example, snagged a 9.7% first-quarter gain scouring U.S. companies with market caps from $1 billion to $10 billion for undervalued stocks -- essentially those with a price-to-sales ratio of 1.5 or less "so we pay no more than $1.50 for every dollar in sales," says Hennessy Funds president Neil Hennessy. These are then screened for earnings momentum (or rising annual profits) and relative strength over three-, six- and 12-month  periods. At the end of March, three of the top five holdings were retailers -- Big Lots (BIG), Dollar Tree Stores (DLTR) and Men's Wearhouse (MW), which rallied 37%, 27% and 23%, respectively, in the first quarter.   While one of the market's chief fears is the impact that lending constrictions   will have on home prices and America's wealth effect -- this has sent the Consumer Discretionary Select SPDR (XLY) down 5.5% since mid-February -- Hen-nessy still has considerable faith in consumers' spending power. "The realities of the world haven't changed that much, even with the market correction," he says. "We still have historically low interest rates, unemployment and inflation."   What we won't have, however, is yet another quarter of outsized earnings growth. After a record 14 quarters of double-digit profit improvement, earnings for S&P 500 companies are projected by Thomson Financial to creep up just 3.8% in the first quarter. As a result, conspicuous profit growth could become a scarcer and more coveted thing. In what may be a hint of things to come, both large- and small-cap growth funds nudged ahead of their value counterparts in the latest quarter, after years of underperformance.   Daniel Frascarelli, director of large-cap core equity investments at Lord Abbett, has been "tilting toward growth" as the economic expansion gets long in the tooth. More specifically, he's gravitating toward not just "GARP-y stocks" that can deliver "growth at a reasonable price," but also larger, liquid names that offer stability and that derive more of their revenue from faster-growing overseas economies.   Among his picks are Monsanto (MON), the agricultural-products, seeds and genomics giant that stands to capitalize on a booming global economy's demand for better crops; Gilead Sciences (GILD), which, among other things, has a growing HIV/AIDS franchise; and Procter & Gamble (PG), whose ability to distribute Gillette products through P&G channels has continued to boost profit growth since the two merged.   Meanwhile, videogame makers like Activision (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (ERTS) still should see sales ride a  surge of interest following the rollout of new-generation consoles from Nintendo, Sony (SNE) and Microsoft (MSFT). Other favored stalwarts include Clorox (CLX), Colgate-Palmolive (CL) and PepsiCo (PEP). "Colgate, for example, has done a great job of taking market share from smaller companies in the fragmented Latin American market," Frascarelli says, and the company's geographically diverse revenue source is a plus as U.S. economic growth slows.   First-quarter gains point to persistent expectations for accelerated expansion overseas, and global funds outperformed their U.S. counterparts in virtually every category. The 96 international small/mid-cap growth funds jumped 6.2% -- while Pacific Region funds added 4.2%; European region funds, 4.3%; and Latin American funds, 4.6%.   The U.S. market has been led by utilities and material stocks' 9% surge, and telecoms' 7% gain. The Rydex Sector Rotation Fund (RYAMX), for instance, whose stock selection is dictated by the market's momentum, currently has more than 25% of its assets concentrated in basic-materials stocks. It has benefited in particular from exposure to smaller material stocks; the S&P 400 mid-cap materials index and the S&P 600 small-cap materials benchmark were each up 12% in the quarter, compared with the S&P 500 materials index, up 8.4%.   Takeover speculation, particularly fervent in the metals and mining segment, plays a big part. "Slowing economic growth could take some of the steam off," says John Escario, a portfolio manager with Rydex Basic Materials Fund (RYBIX), which was up 10.8% in the quarter. And a deepening housing downtown could crimp the forest-products segment. But he expects these to be offset by rising demand for construction materials, driven by the continued boom in non-residential building, and metals, spurred by overseas economies like China.   What were some of the first quarter's surprises? Gold didn't shine, despite economic uncertainty and growing doubts about monetary-policy direction. Gold funds posted a measly gain of just 0.75%.   "Maybe people don't see gold as a perfect hedge for a softening economy anymore," Lipper analyst Tjornehoj says. Some investors have also gravitated toward baskets of global commodities and financial options and futures to hedge the risk of a slowing U.S. economy. And maybe investors see no need for safe havens, and just expect the U.S. economy and stock market to keep chugging ahead.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(4/9) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Global Payments - GPN-NYSE     Outperform - Price 35.88 on April 3   by Barrington Research     GPN, a high-volume processor of electronic transactions, had third-quarter 2007 EPS of 44 cents -- [beating] our expectations and consensus...of 41 cents. Excluding stock-option expense, GPN is expecting total company operating margins between 21.9% and 22.1%, versus 22.4% in fiscal year '06 . . . . Raising our FY07 EPS estimate from $1.83 to $1.86; lowering our FY08 EPS estimate from $2.10 to $2. We believe that GPN's preliminary guidance for FY08 has reduced the level of growth expectations yet, coupled with the FDC/KKR deal, has opened a window of opportunity to purchase the shares at below private-market value. Raising to Outperform; initial price target, 46.     Napster - NAPS-NNM     Buy - Price 4.45 on April 3   by Maxim Group     NAPS preannounced better-than-expected F4Q07 subscriber and revenue growth; AOL conversions slightly below expectations. What should investors do? We [reiterate] Buy. While most of the NAPS' upside return potential is from a takeout, [we think] management is improving execution. NAPS continues to enter agreements in high-growth market segments, notably in mobile: ATT NTT DoCoMo; and KDDI. And we believe NAPS is cutting its sales and marketing expenses, narrow[ing] its cash burn . . . . NAPS didn't provide updated F4Q07 EPS guidance, but our modeling suggests that the upside in organic subscribers narrowed its loss-per-share by about one cent, so we are adjusting our F4Q07 loss-per-share forecast to 20 cents, from 21 cents. Management guided to [a 21-cent loss].     StealthGas - GASS-NNM     Buy - Price 13.88 on April 3   by Cantor Fitzgerald     We raise our price target to 17 (from 15) based on an 8 times EV/2007 [enterprise value] multiple to our new 2007 Ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization] estimate of $47 million (from $45 million). StealthGas announced the acquisition of four [liquid-petroleum gas] carriers (three secondhands and one new) for an aggregate price of $51 million. We expect these acquisitions to be financed by approximately 90% debt and 10% equity. As a result, we raise our 2007 and 2008 EPS estimates to $1.50 (from $1.46) and $1.71 (from $1.58), respectively, to account for latest acquisitions, as well as charter extensions for six LPG carriers. We also raise our Ebitda estimates to $47 million (from $45 million) for 2007 and $53 million (from $47 million) for 2008. GASS has secured 85%+ of its fleet operating days for 2007, which should provide relatively stable earnings and help support current dividend policy. The stock is currently trading at a dividend yield of 5.4%. Notwithstanding these acquisitions, we expect StealthGas to remain moderately leveraged (forecasting 47% long-term debt-to-total capital by year end 2007), which should enable GASS to continue consolidating . . . . Maintaining Buy.     SunTrust Banks - STI-NYSE     Market Perform - Price 81.85 on April 3   by Punk, Ziegel & Co.     Lowering target to 86 from 96. Earnings estimates are being adjusted: a) '07 forecast is being cut to $5.92 per share from $6.09; b) the '08 estimate is being reduced to $6.49 per share from $6.67; and c) the '09 estimate is being reduced to $6.98 per share from $7.18 per share . . . . The stock has a premium multiple [because it's] believed to be a takeover target and has a sizable Coca Cola stake, acquired in 1904, worth an estimated $2.5 billion. As a result . . . STI has a [high price-to-earnings growth] PEG ratio, 1.84:1 . . . . Takeover does not seem likely since the bank has just restructured management . . . There is relatively high earnings risk in STI [now] . . . . Yet rumors of takeover and the yield may provide some downside protection.     VCA Antech - WOOF-NNM     Market Perform/Speculative - Price 36.13 on April 3   by Morgan Keegan     VCA Antech is U.S.'s largest operator of veterinary-diagnostic laboratories and . . . independent operator of animal hospitals. . . . It can generate above-average growth and strong cash flow by taking advantage of trend toward . . . higher-acuity services for pets, particularly diagnostic. Market Perform rating is based on the shares' current valuation at a 1.8 PEG ratio. VCA Antech had 379 animal hospitals in 37 states as of Dec. 31.  .. . T here are ample opportunities for the company to sustain 4% to 5% internal growth [plus growth through] acquisitions. Its . . . [labs] serve hospitals in all 50 states. This business has yielded same-store growth of 15% in the past two quarters . . . [well above an] 8% to 10% target, and generates Ebitda margins of 40%.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  April 07, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
